I'm not getting Boss Bottled from this. It's not around any more except from the eBay scalpers, but this smells a lot like Jaguar "Prestige" EDT and performs like it. Coach for Men, Calvin Klein "Obsession Night" EDTs also come to mind. I know there's a Middle Eastern scent on my shelves that also smells like this, Armaf "All You Need is Love" which also smells nice for about two hours tops. Fruity, sweet, but not excessively so. A little green from patchouli, vetiver and moss. But really unimpressive performance. I was hoping for better, but it's typical of Mont Blanc EDPs to perform like an EDT. Nice bottle and sprayer. Good for date wear, but if you wear it to the office you'd definitely respray at lunch. Completely inoffensive, likeable and priced reasonably at the right discounters.

First Pass - Sweet. Fruity. Subdued. Hint of sourness. This reminds me of Lacoste French Panache. Or rather I should say French Panache reminds me of Emblem Absolu, since this fragrance came out 2 years earlier

1 Hour Later - A faint trace of spice. Still very sweet

2 Hours Later - Delicate and soft, some wisps of woody earthiness. The sour note I smelled at the top is still hanging around, barely, almost musty now. The sweetness continues to accrue. Too sweet to feel masculine now

Looking at the build pear makes perfect sense for a mild, fruit sweetness. Surprised to see Mandarin Orange, I don't get citrus at all...

Cardamom or Pink Pepper could have given the spice. No surprise to see honey, it's very sweet

I don't know what the culprit could be for the sour/musty note, but I find it reminiscent of damp cardboard. It is slight, almost not there, but just enough that I find it distracting

Overall - Lacoste French Panache is similar to this scent. I love that cologne, and although I discovered it first, it's hard to imagine Lacoste's designer wasn't taking notes from Mont Blanc

While I like French Panache better, it almost certainly couldn't exist without Emblem Absolu. It's not nearly as sweet, nor does it have the sour/musty note that I find distracting here

Regardless, there's something magical with how both of them handle the lavender & patchouli that I find exceptional

***Scents, like tastes, are subjective. Wear what you like***

review_content: The special edition is similar to the original, minus the neroli. I bought this fragrance, as well as the EdP version, because of its alleged similarities to AF's Fierce.
There are some similarities, but no... it's not Fierce. Fierce has a different expression, a different character of its own, fresher, lighter, more striking, more individual.
This Legend by Montblanc and the EdP version are also excellent, however, there are some notes that stand out and give it a more “formal,” more aromatic, more “fougere” tone. The tonka bean stands out quite a bit.
I recommend either of these fragrances, though.
Fierce has a special place in the collection, always associated with fantastic memories from the beginning of the millennium.

Perfect example of a dumb reach. It smells like fresh shaving cream and apples/dried fruits. The dried fruit note is surprisingly very realistic. I also pick up pineapple with the rind still on it. The pineapple rind and sandalwood notes mingle so well together. Has great performance with high marks in both sillage and longevity. Incredibly affordable on discounter websites, DO NOT buy this at retail price. I recently picked up a 100ml for $34 which is a fantastic value.

The only thing I find off-putting is that Legend opens with a blast of alcohol. That alcohol quickly subsides into a smooth, great smelling fruity fougere. Is it unique? Not really, but that doesn't make it any less great. This deserves a higher rating in my humble opinion.

This is my third fragrance I've used from Montblanc and every single one has been a great fragrance at a great value.

It don't get people saying it's a lavender bomb. Pour un Homme de Caron is a lavender bomb, not this. Montblanc Legend is a fruity, fresh, woody scent. Nothing lavender in there. Thus it is an "affordable designer" like Calvin Klein, Lacoste or Ralph Lauren. It smells great for what it is but don't compare it to Dior or YSL.

This is a perfect example of a fragrance that isn't great in any way, but for the price you would have it all year round for office / gym / general daily wear. If you just want to smell fresh and clean, but not overbearing, this will do the job.
I'm seeing a lot of hate below for a fragrance that costs £30ish for 50ml, and genuinely smells good.

meh smells like spray deodorants older brother. (spray deodorant is a 14yr freshman while legend is a 18 year old senior) it isn't bad but overall very meh. projection is good but doesn't last to long. it's the type of scent most Millennials would think of if you said cologne. it's very reminiscent of a European uncle who oversprays his cheap drug store cologne (but slighty better and not headache inducing) but at the same time reminds me of a high school lockerroom after gym where the guys are spraying entry level frags and spray deo (with the Bo because to me when I put my nose to it there is a slight vinegar smell, but the vinegar doesn't project). overall outdated and for young guys 4/10, but for guys maybe 30 or so a decent 5.5/10 for going to the store or casual shopping!

I blind bought this looking for a fruit-centered fragrance. Now I didn't expect a gourmand fruit, I expected a fruit forward aromatic fougere. What I got was a skinscent.

Disappointed.
Synthetic, vague, weak. Sits so close to the skin you can barely fucking smell it. There's an ambivalent notion of fruitiness here. It's muted and sits behind a kind of Dr Frankenstein's test-tube lavender? These notes are supposed to be "Pineapple & "Red apple". I have to believe it, but there's no way I would have guessed it without looking at the "cheat sheet". This is fucking BS. I know what pineapple & red apple smells like. I'm sure everybody does. Even cheap, synthetic smelling shampoos usually get their notes right. So why is it so hard for Montblanc?

It's not a bad smelling fragrance. What drives me mad is the mediocricy of it.

Poor projection. Poor longevity.
Waste of money. Glad I bought the 30 ml. Will never buy anything from Montblanc again, since I disliked Explorer as well.

Only thing to keep in mind is the price: it can be easily be found for 30€/100ml on many sites.

Great fragrance for the price. Fresh and clean, perfect daily wear whether it's the gym, school, work or just running errands. Easy to wear with decent performance; might need to be heavy on the sprays around 8 to 10 and respray after 4 to 5 hrs to get all-day longevity.

Nose Note #635

I have a 50ml of Al Rehab For Men and the two are very similar, except this is indeed a little fruity, but don't expect it to be like a fruit bowl. This is first and foremost an aromatic lavender fragrance that has a 90s vibe. It's kind of soapy, clean smelling, but not modern. And you may have previously smelled this DNA in Axe Apollo and some other Axe, which are in some places more popular than MB Legend or Fierce.

Hard to describe exactly what it smells like. You have to be familiar with the note of lavender. To my nose it has mild to little sweetness. The fruity aspect is very fuzzy to me. The scent is very memorable.

8/10, a good one for all ages and seasons. Maybe buy something else for a formal occasion

"Life is good, but it can be better" Maxwell Lord.
This is a great scent, fruity... vanilla... perfect for year round wear to freshen up for any occasion. But it's extremely average. Would people buy a $70-$100 clone of a decade & a half old fragrance such as Versace Eros? No. So why does Mont Blanc do it. Well Mont Blanc undeniably has good quality fragrances. So why don't they use that to their advantage. Their most popular scents are clones. Their most underrated ones are the more "original" ones, still clinging onto the similar counterparts DNA. Hopefully soon I can get Presence and speak more about this. But until then, Go ahead and get this if you want a decent daily, might come off as a bit outdated but nothing drastic. There are multiple choices that I think are more worth the price point.
Lovely top notes with a decent dry down. Projection is decent but longevity is not great

This fragrance is a mystery for me.
When I was younger, I had this same exact perfume, and it smelled okay, kind of deodorant-ish, but it was usable, and it lasted for a reasonable amount of time on my skin.
I recently found a closed bottle of Montblanc Legend at my dad's house, stored perfectly, and it has little to no smell and the longevity is null. To test if it wasn't just out of date, I went to a perfume shop, to test it out. The results were the same. Little to no smell and bad longevity.
Safe to say, once, or even if this bottle ends, I will not buy Montblanc Legend again.
I'd much more recommend Montblanc Legend Blue to whoever wants to buy this, because it has a very similar smell, while projecting it more.

I don't understand the people saying it has poor projection or lasting power. I only need 2-3 sprays and it lasts 8-12 hours on my skin. It smells almost exactly like A+F Fierce, but I love it. Lots of compliments.

I really like this fragrance because it immediately brings me back to when I would wear A&F Fierce. Unfortunately, the performance is so bad, I don't even consider it something I would wear out of the house. I just wear it at home in the evenings after a shower. I've let it sit for a while - hoping the projection/longevity would step up, but it only slightly improved.

I would recommend grabbing it if you want something nostalgic and just for yourself.

I agree with the user boomwakr. It a Dark/ Dirty Lavender Scent that becomes sweeter overtime although not exactly "fruity" to me. Very solid choice given the price point. Man, I have to say I love it. The sweet fruitiness mixed with the lavender is very addictive. Excellent. Really good, safe fragrance. There is nothing revolutionary here whatsoever. Sort of reminds me of Coach for men. Longevity and sillage are moderate at best. This is not a beast mode projector by any means. I get quite a lot of the top notes, and it doesn't seem to be overly sweet as others have remarked. Smells like a very classic barbershop type of fougere, which are among my favorites. This is a very standard gentleman's fragrance that would work in many different settings. I'm curious about the EDP version now. If you're looking for something "niche" and "different", this ain't it.

It's objectively good in my opinion when you consider important variables.

Not a love since it's nothing crazy out of the ordinary, but you might love it, and others might too. Explorer and Legend are pretty cost effective ones to try in my opinion.

I like original legend more than legend spirit, which I also have, which is also nice.

Very fruity and fresh. But so abysmally weak. I am not joking, I put 20 sprays on and it only lasted and performed decently because of that. So watered down. Might be worth picking up just because it’s so cheap. But other than that, meh
Its okay, too mature IMO. Smells like something my uncle would wear lol. Fierce is much better.

Legend is a very pleasant scent that I like but don't love. It has a traditional fresh barbershop appeal that's entirely likeable but also a bit generic smelling. It's a clean scent that's marked mostly by a bright floral and fruity - but not overly sweet - accord once it dries down. It has pretty average longevity and only moderate projection, so it's a safe office scent. It's also very versatile for pretty much any season or occasion and it's a safe blind buy. This is one of those colognes I'm happy to have though I never really get excited about wearing it.

Really nice scent that doesn’t last on my skin. Almost zero projection and a skin scent from the beginning. My bottle is authentic. This can help you smell nice and subtle… emphasis on subtle! It isn’t as “fruity” as I expected it to be based on what I had read from others. Fresh apple, lavender & woods. Very aromatic. Nice, clean, wear anywhere scent. Signature scent worthy, just lacks performance which makes it a tough go for me. Bottle is nice quality. Atomizer on mine is below average.

Overall: 7.5 out of 10

Ok, here goes. I am very feminine so never mind the men's label on this as I had only wanted to go back in time and smell the headshop like scent of an Abercrombie and Fitch Store. Instead of buying Fierce though, I had bought Montblanc Legend after being told that it was somehow an even better version of Abercrombie's Fierce. I had to heavily respray as I could not distinguish any of the notes. I was almost in denial that so many reviewers could be so wrong, plus the A.I. review online confirming that Fierce is what they had sprayed in the stores to lure in their customers. I was thinking how bad can it be as I love lavender and sandalwood? I do not mind a good spicy bergamot, and it was only $28 with my coupons and discounts. So, mostly this was to satisfy my curiosity. I'm sure it is genuine. The bottle is lovely. I was actually excited to receive this. I was praying as I was spraying that it would evoke old memories at the mall. I was even planning to spray this on a towel in my laundry and then go in there to see what the waft was like. I tried it on my skin where I only get a sharp sweet opening that is mostly meh bergamot that's more like a dank lime bathroom cleaner if I had to guess. There's no lavender detected at all and there's no lemon verbena (I am a gardener who knows and a frag head). Heaven only knows what those strange middle notes are. I wait for the dry down, still praying of course, come on Sandalwood / Vanilla, where are y'all, but there is nothing! Next, we do the outdoor wind test. Legend EDT is a classic – I don't care what anyone says. It's funny how you go through different phases...... Legend EDT was one of my first buys when I got into fragrances, and I thought it was fantastic. Over time I sort of outgrew it, and began to find it rather adolescent... for a while I thought the EDP was better... but lately I'm back to really appreciating the merits of this EDT.

It's a great DNA – sweet (but not too much), and just enough complexity to make it incredibly versatile. Totally works as a gym scent, yet has some classy sophistication to it as well. It's not overpowering, so it's great for work, and the scent stays pleasing from opening to dry-down. It's inexpensive, so you can spray it on liberally without concern. It's just good all the way around. Plus at this point, it has that classic element to it, as an old-school DNA stretching back over 20 years to A&F Fierce.

So yeah.... I'm back to spraying this on from time to time, and enjoying it. (When I'm in the right mood for that adolescent pineapple note....)

Years ago, I would’ve written this off as a “generic men’s cologne” scent alongside the likes of Bleu de Chanel and Montblanc Explorer; fuzzy, dark, clean, and typically-masculine are adjectives that come to mind, yet I’ve come to appreciate these facets nowadays.

Legend EDT rightly gets compared very often to Abercrombie and Fitch’s “Fierce” (a fragrance I cherish immensely), yet its nuances of dense lavender and dark, restrained fruitiness contrast with Fierce’s sharp and bright citrus/pine laid atop a dense-yet-clean musk. Legend presents a smooth, melancholic tone not found in the very uplifting Fierce.

“A hazier, fruitier Fierce” would describe this very well. The fruits are hard to decipher, but seeing “red apple” and “dried fruits” in the note breakdown sounds right. Only now that I’ve nearly finished my 1 oz bottle do I finally detect the woody pineapple poking through, realizing it was a large contributor to the hard-to-place fruity accords from the very beginning.

The scent is linear, with only the initial zingy, alcoholic and somewhat-harsh opening settling down into a subdued and muted form rather swiftly, lasting into the drydown. It doesn’t have room-clearing strength, but it performs strongly for a couple hours with 3 sprays then fades into a more personal scent. However, I feel that the initial wall of scent makes me partially-noseblind to some of its later projection. Your results may vary.

Overshadowed by other fragrances in my collection, I won’t be rebuying this, but if it means anything to you, this fragrance ascended from being a last-resort stashed away in my glovebox to being a daily wear for a couple of months during Spring.

Montblanc Legend is a fragrance that pleasantly surprised me with its inoffensive yet appealing clean scent. If I discovered this scent earlier, and if it were not for Parfums de Marly Percival existing now, I would have considered buying and wearing Montblanc Legend for sure.

However, we have Percival now, which comes as an EDP and not only boasts incredible longevity, but also exudes a more exciting aroma, spicing things up. Percival is the modern final boss of this fragrance DNA and comes at a reasonable price point (performance and quality considered), unlike Creed Aventus, for which Montblanc Explorer is a great alternative.

I briefly thought about buying Legend for times when I didn't want to use up my Percival bottle, but I realized that's a bit silly. After all, we should just wear the best scent we want, when we want. If you are on a budget though, get this one.

This fragrance is in my hall of fame list. It is a classy masculine evening fragrance. I am not a big fan of strong leather, woods or patchouli so this hit all the marks for me. All the accords are bold and wrapped in a lavender bubble. On the top you get the lavender with a touch of bergamot and a hint of lemon verbena. At times I would get pineapple when it starts to dry . But it's so faint and for a short time . In the middle you get the dried fruits rose and geranium. The rose will linger until the fragrance fades away. But it's so mixed with the lavender that you know the rose is there but you don't get very much of it . The apple you don't get until it's fully dried down and everything is settled. Maybe an hour later . The oakmoss comes out very little as well. The sandalwood isn't very strong at all . It add just enough wood to carry everything and not disrupt much of what's going on. Same for the tonka , it's the warm sugar dusting over the top. Everything just works so well while being kept classy by the lavender. While it is more of a formal fragrance it can be dressed down a little. But it's definitely an evening date night type of fragrance.
Performance, for being an edt it has pretty strong performance. On clothing I have smelled it the next day. On skin I have smelled it 8 to 9 hours later. Projection , with 4 sprays you'll get a solid 2 to 3 hours.

I've decided I really enjoy the Fierce DNA in general and have looked into several of its copycats. It's an any-time-of-day, any-time-of-year kind of scent which I tend to favor, and it isn't overly sweet.

Legend, while more fruity and sweet than its predecessor, definitely shares that classic vibe with its signature aromatic-musky-woody theme.

I don't think the longevity of Fierce is any better than Legend, but I haven't given them a side-by-side test yet.

If I had to choose between the two on scent alone, I'd stick with Fierce as it's less sweet, but when you factor in price (Legend is usually less than half as much as Fierce on discounters), Legend becomes much more appealing.

It's definitely not an exact copy, but if you're looking for something in the Fierce genre and want to save a few bucks, or if you think Fierce would smell better with a little sweetness, I'd say Legend is a worthy substitute.

Mont Blanc Legend, an aromatic fougere with fruity sweetness, accompanies you effortlessly throughout the year, transitioning from crisp spring mornings to cozy fall nights. It's a fragrant tale of contrasts, uniting strength with tenderness, tradition with modernity. The weighty bottle, adorned in black and metallic hues, draws inspiration from the renowned Meisterstück pen. Minimalistic and opulent, its design mirrors the essence of the fragrance within.

From skin to paper, Mont Blanc Legend transforms—a clean, formal scent. It's not avant-garde, rather universally embraced in any context. Lavender and pineapple lead the symphony, followed by red apple and dried fruits. As the fragrance unfurls, tonka bean and sandalwood form its warm, lasting core. Imagine a world where layers of fresh citrus, sweet fruitiness, and a comforting heart intertwine. It's a versatile companion that adapts seamlessly to every scenario.

For those reminiscent of Abercrombie & Fitch's Fierce, Mont Blanc Legend beckons with familiarity and holds the promise of approval. I recall wearing it in a quaint Milanese linen shop years ago—the Italian ladies couldn't help but inquire about the captivating trail. Thus, the mystique of Mont Blanc's magnetism continues to flourish.

Montblanc Legend is a fruitier take on Fierce. Ironically I got this after loving Legend Eau de Parfum and Explorer from the house of Montblanc. Legend lives up to it, but I kind of wish I got it before Legend EDP.

Montblanc Legend has a fruity lavender open. There is some bergamot and a slight lemon verbena to it but the star is pineapple. It isn't Aventus level, but it is close. The mid is not that off from another Fierce clone that I want to say came out the same year, Playboy New York. You do not get the fantasy note of vinyl here but rather the apple note along with some dried fruits and I want to say pineapple is one of these. The base is woody and tonka. That said Legend EDP is far more woody.

Legend has pretty good performance. It is at least on par with the current Fierce batches. You get some more reigned in projection but the length is where it is on par with Fierce. You get 6/7 hours EASY. Mind you, that is better than most Fierce clones like Playboy New York Police Legend(ary Scent) and the countless Bath & Body Works Men releases that are clones which are slighter both in projection and performance.

I happen to think Montblanc Legend is nearly year round. It maybe too much for summer days but you can wear it for summer nights. I wouldn't wear Legend for clubs but nearly any other occasion will work.

Soft Woody-Floral BRAZILIAN ROSEWOOD with Pepper, Mandarin & Orchid...

In the first few minutes before the spray dries, I can feel the rosewood notes with their rich floral and slightly spicy tones. Once the spray dries and the sillage starts to open up, I get the mandarin & pepper, but the rosewood notes are already swelling through. As it transitions to the heart some soft floral tones emerge with orchid and cyclamen, but the florals, including vanilla-flower, are here more as part of the rosewood accord. In the base there's a trio of woods (rosewood, mahogany & sandalwood) accented by patchouli & soft vanilla-flower. Overall I get a rosewood scent, with all of the other notes serving to enhance and support different facets of rosewood with it's powdery, rosy, velvety, rich-floral, spicy-sweet,creamy-soapy & woody tones. There's also a nostalgic quality for me, that's hard to pinpoint - but more in a down-to-earth way than a vintage perfumery way. This has been a signature scent of mine off and on, since it first came out, and I've been through more than one bottle. Initially this struck me as feminine, however after reading reviews I can see how this may read masculine to some as it has some touches usually reserved for men's cologne. In truth, it's unisex, but regardless anyone could wear it. This isn't a dupe of anything, but it has reminders for me of other rosewood prominent scents like Dune Dior, Rosewood Banana Republic & Midnight Fleur Nest.

Contrast to Rosewood Banana Republic:
These are different, but there are similarities with a forward rosewood. Presence d'une Femme leans spicier, sweeter & more complex. Roughly equivalent performance, or slightly better for Presence d'une Femme.

Overall: gorgeous, unisex Brazilian Rosewood scent profile with average or slightly above average performance. This is the perfect scent to wear for going home, if only in your mind. It's a longtime love for me. Enjoy!

Judging by the notes this is not what I was expecting, thought I was going to get a warm spicy woody vanilla but got a fresh masculine cologne with lots of ambroxan.
Kinda reminds me of the smell of magazines mixed with man cologne and I do actually really like that smell.

What had they claim from above notes doesn't turn out from what I expected. I blind buy this perfume and I am glad I love it. It has the MontBlanc unique vibe similar with Femme Individuelle but is different category. Présence d'une femme can be unisex.

The top note starting up with a fresh chamomile tea but some leather underneath the base note. Is fresh, aromatic and relax.
I can get some patchouli but not a strong patchouli. No sandalwood or woody note detected by my nose.
I believe the orchid play the biggest roles here and the rest notes claim such as patchouli, wood note, pepper, mandarin notes, minor supporting the orchid.

For a EDT, the projectivity is super great value for it price. the longevity is great for it value.

I will say this is not a safe blind buy for people who love flowery, soft, cotton, warm like perfume.
If you love, Femme Individuelle, you will definitely love Présence d'une femme.

For a woman's perfume, i love the way this smells on the skin after it settles down a bit.
Definitely unique and a woody.
Floral and sweet.
Love smelling this on a woman, but a man can wear this scent too.
9/10

I usually don't write bad reviews, but with this fragrance I feel it may be justified. However, I will start with the positives first.

This is my first and only Montblanc fragrance and if I was the kind of person who liked fragrances that smell like Shampoo, like a tumble dryer sheet and clean. Then I'd be over the moon with this. But im not.

This fragrance is very misleading and I thought that I was going to get something ambery, woody, warm spices, autumnal and good for the cold weather, but I did not.

Those accents don't exist in the construction of this fragrance, despite the note listing but what I do get is a very, synthetic, longlasting, ambroxan bomb 💣.

I have to admit that I was so shocked and disappointed 😞 when I tested the fragrance and I can't see where, when or why, ill ever wear this fragrance. Its boring, insipid and generic and if this is what the brand puts out, then its definitely overrated, which is a shame.

I really should give top marks for the bottle though..It reminds me of the Nivea bottle; but this one is more like a UFO, and its huge and awkward to hold in your hand.

This one is odd to me. At first spray and for quite awhile, I smell green grass, a spring-summer vibe. It's def not in the notes. I can't reconcile the notes with what is in my nose. As it dries down, it mellows into something more warm and spicy and less intensely, offputtingly fresh. Fresh is my least favorite scent profile. I am not sure I will keep it, but it was a great buy so I may hang onto it and just see if it gets better with age. The bottle is just weird, sitting on its sprayer end, but looks cool on the table.

I am new to the fragrance world so bear with me. This is my third time wearing this fragrance. The first time I thought it was nice but not my type. The second time I thought it was quite nice and maybe I would wear it to work. This time, wow it's stunning! This could easily be worn to the office, but there is something alluring about this fragrance that would make it perfect for sensuous, intimate nights. I don't find it overly feminine or particularly masculine and feel this could work for both. When I first tried this perfume, it was Winter. It is now Spring in the Southern Hemisphere and I think that has made all the difference. So I would definitely say it works better in Spring and Autumn, but am yet to see how it performs in Summer. Projection is arms length and possibly more, sillage is reasonable, longevity was down to a skin scent by the 6 hour mark. Overall, a nice affordable fragrance.

I bought this unsniffed because it got good reviews and because I like another Montblanc feminine fragrance, Femme Individuelle. Michele Almairac was the perfumer for both, and Presence d'Une Femme and Femme Individuelle smell related to me. Both have pepper, patchouli and vanilla, while Presence has more woods and vanilla, Individuelle has more floral and fresh notes. While either could be worn day or night, spring or fall, I would tend to see Individuelle as the more daytime/spring scent and Presence as the more evening/fall scent. I think both are versatile, affordable scents.

I bought a tester bottle of this perfume. when I first sprayed this on I was not sure, it smelt quite fruity, sweet and feminine which isn't really to my tastes. I was ready to not like it from there however as soon as it settled into my skin, I was surprised with how addictive this perfume really is. It makes me picture an exquisite and fashionable woman wearing a black pantsuit, branded sunnies, hair in a neat bun with some strands escaping just to delicately frame her face, dark lipstick, and she is striding with confidence and purpose on the streets of Milan
this perfume lingers on me, and I keep catching a waft of it for hours. I notice when it wafts, I inhale deeply just to enjoy as much of the scent as I can. Needless to say, I love it and am keeping this in my collection

I love this. I've had this since around Thanksgiving. I haven't worn it much, but I'm sure going to. I'm not keen on the first few minutes. But after that, I love it. I think it's ideal for cooler weather.

Boy oh boy, Mont Blanc does not disappoint! Their creations are of a sophisticated, rich smelling kind, and this is not the exception. I'll be completely honest: this was a crazy crazy purchase because I knew nothing about it, so it was completely blind. I am so glad I took the risk and went rogue buying it without even knowing anything about it because it is sooo good! It is carefully woody (well blended). It was crafted with expert and exquisite taste and detail. It smells expensive but it's not. Nobody talks about it and nobody knows about it, so I feel like a fortunate secret keeper. This is my fourth Mont Blanc. I also own Signature, Lady Emblem Elixir and my latest gem along side this one: Individuelle. Lord am I fortunate.

This would smell incredible on a dude.
What a gorgeous inexpensive gem!
Seriously tho- Montblanc makes very well constructed, long lasting scents. I’m super impressed.
This smells current- perhaps the herbal sage & pineapple gives me Aventus vibes? It definitely skews masculine to me.
Gonna find out if my husband is into it.
What a happy surprise!

This is my latest blind buy and OMG yes! I fell head over heels for it. This is a floral wood-vanilla combo. A bit aromatic too. I get a soft Chamomile Tea aroma all the way, so unique.

The opening is a blast of Mandarin and pepper. As it dries down I get a delicate floral aromatic scent and finally, it settles down on a woody vanilla base that my skin seems to love.

People are very occupied by the masculine or feminine aspect of it. Do not! This is simply an amazing scent, round, well constructed, unique, elegant and not for the faint-hearted. I picture a strong and confident person wearing this fragrance.

Also long lasting - 6 sprays lasts for 8 hours on my skin and longer on clothes. Sillage is reasonable.

I am in love ❤️

I want to love this, but there's just too much orange here for me.
I feel that the comments about it smelling masculine are rather strange as I found it to be distinctly feminine.
Very smooth and fresh, warm and ambery. The orangey note is very nice but I am not keen on orange in perfumery at all, which is why it's off putting for me, so the note is not a detriment to the scent - it just isn't for me.
Lasts well, soft projection.

I think this one is unique, special. Although nobody says it and in his notes it does not appear, it smells like tea to me. A tea with mild spices, somewhat woody, with a hint of citrus and a few drops of vanilla. I see that many think that it leans to the masculine side, but for me it's more in the middle, inclined to the feminine side. I didn't like it the first time I smelled it but since I already had it (it was a blind buy) I gave it more opportunities ... and I fell for it. Now every time I use it I really do enjoy it. It's long lasting and has moderate sillage. It's my SOTD, and 8 hours after having applied it (generously) I still can clearly perceive it. And I find it very versatile, suitable for use all year round, day or night (except maybe in the hottest days of summer).
I really love it and can't believe how affordable it was. As soon as I finish it, if it's still available I will buy it again, for sure.

I was going down memory lane and was looking for the 1999 fragrance by Adrienne Vittadini or something similar - and this is definitely it! It leans unisex but is still quite feminine. It has a noticable presence yet remains polite, making it suitable for the workplace and formal occasions. Slightly synthetic opening, however that fades within seconds and develops into an aromatic semi-sweet woody vibe.

For me, the performance is 4-6 hours and has a very pleasant dry down. I would consider this a mature scent, ages 25+

I've owned this scent since Christmas; it's about time I admit this blind buy was not a success. I love scents with vanilla/woodsy notes, not overly sweet and with floral notes. Based on the notes, I had assumed it would be right up my alley. Not so much...This thirty-something cannot pull off this powdery business-scent.

The scent itself is lovely. The vanilla and woodsy notes really are warm and soft, the pepper makes for a spicy little twist. I get wafts every now and then. It's present, not screaming for attention. I think it's the patchouli that makes it masculine/aloof. The warmness never gets cozy. It's a business woman all the way. She does not immediately stand out, but she demands a second look. And, you have to admire how well put-together she is.
Unfortunately, she's not me.

She is up for swaps for anyone in the Netherlands, if you can handle her.

I’ve been wearing Présence d'une for the past 5 hours and it’s still going, so very good performance. Indeed, Présence leans slightly masculine (and I’m a female who has always enjoyed masculine scents). This is for anyone to enjoy,....a good one to check out.

Identifying specific notes in this composition—beyond the obvious pepper and wood notes—is difficult for me. Maybe there’s vanilla here, but it’s with a light hand. Initially I thought I loved Présence (and I did for the first hour) then Présence either developed or my nose grew tired of it. If I had to pinpoint the reason, I’m guessing too much iso e super, or another synthetic used, which is also why this thing is a performance monster of a perfume.

In any case, I’m convinced this is a good, intriguing scent though I’m not compelled to run out and buy it—even though I almost did just that—as it’s going for a steal on fragrencenet.

I’m glad I waited to sample first.

I first fell in love with this frag in 2002 just watching the bottle: a round shaped silver base, the transparent round glass…it reminded me of a pebble, and it was really pleasant to keep in your hand.
superb design, innovative, classic and sophisticated.
That’s what I though about the scent when first spritzed it: sophisticated.
An elegant, but decided woman that is classic yet sensual, mysterious and irresistible.

This perfume is never overpowering, it opens with a fresh scent that blends with tangerine. Then it reveals a modern floral bouquet, and I find the dry down irresistible: powdery, a little oriental, sexy and very very delicate and clean. Stays on all day. Enrobes you with sensuality. A delicate vanilla patchouli with a balsamic woodiness.

Some reviewers in other blogs have written about pineapples notes – I have used 3 bottles of this fabulous fragrance without noticing any pineapple note.
Then I went to check the actual pyramid (see below) and it turns out that only the leaves of pineapples were used, not the fruit.. :o)

I always receive many compliments when wearing that.

_____________________________________________
Pyramid:
Top note: Pineapple leaf, tangerine, pepper
Middle note: Cyclamen, orchid
Base note: sandalwood, rosewood, vanilla flower, patchouli

Finally bought it, blind buy, i was expecting something sweet and bold because it is classified as Oriental Vanilla, but i smell no vanilla, at all. I find this fresh citrussy, kinda like a men cologne, i get why so many reviews said this is very masculine. I also reminded of Mugler perfumes at the first 1 minute, maybe the patchouli, but in the lighter version of Angel. Not great nor bad, it is pleasant but very light, i don't know if people will notice me wearing this or not.

@rickyflicky. This bottle is round and flat (sort of like a thick pancake). It is quite solid in the hand and does not look or feel cheap at all. More importantly, the scent is quite unique and lovely. Not the usual fruity, suntan lotion summer scent.

I hope this helps.
I plan to blind buy this, never smell it nor see it. I just love the bottle design. But can someone tell me is the bottle heavy or thin? Is it made with good material? Thank you before 🙏🙏

This was a blind buy for me in my hunt for my next signature fragrance. I tend to like the warmer fragrances, and Burberry Women was my go to for years. After that was Tonka by Reminiscence. This one starts with a powerful and "In your face" opening and then dries down to a sweet, warm, and skin close scent. Overall a good pick just buying based on the notes and the reviews. I wish this was a bit stronger on the base, as that is my favorite part of this fragrance. But it's not a big deal to reapply since the opening is very brief and quickly dries down to the part I love the most.
The opening is a very strong, but pleasant and brief, Orange peel and pepper (more orange than pepper). Kinda like peeling an orange and the oils the peel leaves behind on your fingers. As it's drying a soft floral scent which is neither too sweet nor too feminine. Base is very nice mahogany and a soft, sweet, and warm vanilla scent. Not an offensive fragrance, in my opinion, and the base could actually afford to be stronger. This one sits close to the skin for me once it dries and I find myself re-applying once around mid-day. Could definitely be used as unisex, but as I am a very big fan of "masculine" scents, I'm keeping this for myself!

Woody, slightly masculine and still feminine enough. I smell rosy woods with a hint of orange and sharp pepper. There's warm vanilla too and I can smell sandalwood. This would be a great scent during the fall. After a while the vanilla note deepens into a even warmer, sweeter one. This composition is nice!

I can see why some ladies find this a touch masculine. I'm wearing it in warm conditions and it really comes into its own.

It's a "I mean business" scent but I'm also feminine.
The wood notes are the unisex element but the sweet orange, orchid and vanilla remind you that I'm a lady.

I wasn't sure about the pepper note but I find it much better in the warm atmosphere. It keeps it bright.
Not bad longevity and sillage for an edt either.

If you are looking for a modern, crisp scent for work then this worth checking out. It smells way more expensive than it costs.

To sum it up, it's Mandarin Woodiness.

I love Mandarin and Mahogany so works for me perfectly.

It falls in the same vein as CK Euphoria, but not the same smell, Euphoria is Pomegranate Mahogany and this is Mandarin Mahogany. So if you like Euphoria, you will definitely like this as well.

Decent longevity.

Edit: What a beauty! the more I use it the more I love it. And in all honesty, I don't find it leaning more masculine.

It opens with orange and slight pepper kick.. fresh n uplifting.. then some florals.. the interesting part is in the drydown.. i can still smell the orange from the top note mixed with vanilla which gives a bit creamy sweet smell and smooth woody note which i guess coming from the sandalwood.. overall i really like this scent.. longevity is good 6 to 8 hours.. moderate projection for 1 to 2 hours.. never become skin scent to me.. its soften but always presence.. so i guess the name fit its character..

I bought this blind hoping that it would smell like Dune because of similar notes. This one is not as dry as Dune and has a prominent vanilla note. It is also sweeter. It stays close to the skin.
It is unisex, fresh and woodsy.

I really love some male fragrances from Mont Blanc, moreover I sometimes love my husband's perfumes so much i get myself thinking "I wish they did a female version of this". usually that's not what happens, the female versions are completely different and relate close to nothing to the their male counterparts. So I bought a sample of this and then I felt like they did, in this perfume, the magic I have been waiting for: turned a male perfume slightly to the female side. Certainly it will not fit everyone, but they kept the masculine character just on point, I really like it and will definitely buy it.

So wonderful on my skin. I feel sexy, compelling, and powerful when I wear this.

Its almost masculine. Its what I would want to wear when competing with the boy's club in CEO business meetings. It would help me show my dominance in a setting where I could use any advantage that I could get.

In that same respect, I would wear it to divorce proceedings with lawyers present. It would scream no nonsense and take no prisoners but without being crazy loud.

The opening was strong and sharp orange/black pepper combo. So spicy that I actually had to check the name of the perfume on my sample to make sure I really have a female version. It seemed totally masculine, so my attention was catched immediately.

The drydown milds the scent into sweet (but not sickly) vanilla, underlined with woodsy notes and a little sign of florals.

It smells clean/fresh, slisghtly sweeter, white, but with some spiciness to it. In my opinion perfect for spring for everyday every night use. Could be unisex. Safe for office work.

I noticed some people said here it's not feminime. To me it is. As I believe there are also women who like to stand out of the crowd and who know how to wear something that is far from girly.

Another lesson learned: Blind buys are great fun with a good deal and good research, but don’t blind buy a perfume you liked as a kid, because your tastes have probably changed. This reminds me of the smell of Abercrombie and Fitch pumped out into the hallways of the mall when I was wearing flared jeans and baby doll tops. It definitely runs to the masculine side of things, but in the cheap teenager first cologne way. I’m not sure I will ever find a way to wear this because it smells so dated. Maybe I’ll keep it a few decades until that type of fragrance becomes a classic, hahaha.

EDIT: okay, in fairness, I owe this perfume a bit of an apology. It was unseasonably warm today and I spritzed a bit on my arm and the fragrance is not nearly so harsh and masculine as it was before. I will keep it in rotation as the weather warms up and hope that maybe it just needs the warm seasons to really come alive.

EDIT 2: yeah, no, on me this is crappy cheap 90’s boy smell.

On me it is completely different from Dune, dry and short lasting without any sweetness.Dune is one of my favorite scents, and on my skin it is sweet (90s sweet, very different from nowadays), comfortable, sophisticated, dreamy and cozy. My mother and I loved Dune (and this is quite difficult to happen, since we have opposite tastes in perfumes) and almost fought over a bottle of it. A beloved, comfort perfume, a classic.
As per Presence it was a huge disappointment, no sweetness,a strange clash of notes without any unifying direction, lasted for 2 hours with light sillage, the worst perfume by Michel Almairac on my skin.

"Presence d'un femme" is a little aromatic, a little spicy, firmly woody, tenderly flowery, sweet-like vanilla and skin-like patchouli.

The perfume opens with very apparent mandarine, but it is not sharp, or zesty, or bitter. Mandarin joined with pepper has a mild aromatic-spicy effect similar to the smell of "dried arancini" (Mediterranean organic sweets made of orange skin sun-dried in sugar, which taste aromatic and peppery).

Nor orchid, or cyclamen are expressively flowery - flowers tame the top concoction, preventing top to become piercing, and bringing peppered mandarine back from spicy to mildly aromatic, before the other big concoction enters the stage: woods and vanilla.

I really can't smell all three woody notes (rosewood, mahogany and sandalwood) - it is just rounded, firm woody complex on me. And then again - it is instantly followed by vanilla, making it rounder and milder. The vanilla-woods combo in base presents powdery-dusty effect, mildly sweet and freshened by remains of peppery-aromatic top. Sometimes I get almond/nutty-like vibe (I guess that's woody-vanilla expression) in this stage of development.
And there is patchouli... I am very sensitive and somehow particular to patchouli iterations (they can thrill me and they can disgust me, I still don't get the pattern, except that this in some cases related to the warm weather). Patchouli is very discrete here - I sense it in the base only as some "warm-skin" presence, but far from anything skanky or noticable enough to provoke reaction.

There is, in fact, some dissonant "maleish" accord present, partly in the peppery-citrus opening, and mostly in woody-vanilla dry down, which works as a subtle contrast to the natural sweetnes of flowers and vanilla. But, it is not dominant at all, and it likes to play "hide and seek". It is like you put on a lovers yesterday's shirt with the remains of his perfume, but you are wearing your own very feminine perfume, and it is dominant. I find that interesting and slightly tempting but, above all, not overwhelming.
I really don't get this "totally masculine" feedbacks on Presence - in my opinion, this slightly masculine accord is the thing that keeps this fragrance away from beeing just another clichè perfume created for oriental-woody-vanilla lovers.

Finally, about that "masculinity"-issue that flooded the reviews below, let's put it this way: the man that I sleep with - wearing Presence d'un femme?
Well... No.
Nope. Can't imagine that. No way. Sorry.
Except - if I leave it on him.
As my presence.

Overall, Presence isn't the best ever, or earth moving fragrance - BUT - it is far from dull, stereotypical or "unproblematic" scents. Also, it is very pleasant and unintrusive, and for daily rotation it has quite enough qualities to be taken into account for FB, or at least for serious testing.

* like ("ok one")
* sillage: moderate (arms lenght)
* longevity: moderate (up to 6 hours)
* discontinued (but still available at affordable prices).
This is definitely on the masculine side. However I am totally in love with it. It starts off crisp and fresh and then becomes something totally different with it's warmth and coziness. Love it.

I smelled this for the first time today. My friend used it to freshen an outdoor space and it was the spiciness that captivated me. It was also crisp, so I tried it on (even though she used it to freshen the air) and I fell in love. It started out crisp and spicy and settled into something warm and cozy by the end of the day. It lasted all day and I was outdoors most of the time. It never was overwhelming or suffocating. I kept smelling myself because it was such a beautiful smell. It was something like no perfume I've ever owned. It was feminine, but with a touch of masculinity. I have to order this now.

The most masculine smelling perfume I've ever tested to this date that is advertised as being a perfume for women. I can smell mandarin orange, pepper and I think wood (though I'm not sure because I'm not very familiar with woody notes - but it's a dry and dusty smell that stays during the whole time). Orchid, vanilla - no idea, my nose couldn't locate them. Longevity - sorry, poor, it stays on my wrist 30 mins max, I believe this is because it's and EDT. Sillage - nonexistent. I wouldn't buy this fragrance myself, but I got it as a gift so I will use it up though it lacks distinction. It's like a watercolor painting - it's there, but it's so sparse and thin, like a ghost of a proper perfume.
Did not like it..... Who wants to swap????
Reminds me sweet minds.Love this.Absolutely masterpiece.

Mmmm. Présence d'un(e)...freshly showered bloke.

Oddly, up close I get some berries and sweetness, yet my aura smells distinctly masculine. Really quite nice, I should say, but more reminiscent of a clean fella on his way to work than une femme.

I think Présence might have been an experiment by Montblanc, aka "What do women most like the smell of? Nice, clean, well-dressed men. By Jove, I think we've got it!"

I tried to get my mind around it being wearable by women too, but after a few hours I got fed up of the olfactory dissonance. I will try it on my man...

As much as love this scent (I even got praises), as much as I'm hesitant to buy/wear it again, because it's obvious that people categorize it more under masculine scents
It is very pleasant scent (specially in winter)
and I'm keen to smell the empty bottle from time to time :)

First of all, i have to say that i got this fragrance from a friend, my female boss, because although it's a nice fragrance, the prices here in Brazil are OVER THE TOP, so wouldn't be worth it.

Anyway, the review:

The main accords of this scent, as described above are woody, balsamic, sweet, powdery, fresh spicy and patchouli. Not for me. I would describe this, in order of importance as Woody, Fresh Spicy and Powdery.

I don't get the balsamic side, or even the patchouli (as i'm used to in other scents).

Presence D'Une Femme is a wonderful simplistic scent. Sexy and classy without making any effort. Whenever i use it, i feel powerful without trying, like, paraphrasing Beyoncé, "i woke up like this".

Downside (at least on my skin) is the poor longevity and projection.

Office friendly, safe for dates and gifts.

(For those of you who knows Brazilian brands, it reminds me a little of the original Glamour, without the citric accord - or a least not that pronounced).
I love this fragrance!! It smell amazingly refreshing, not too powerful but definitely memorable. This one is particularly special and personal to me.
i love this one! there is no perfume which resemles to this one..very woody,unique and distinctive! i would definetely purchase it if its lasting power was stronger!

This is nice and a bit different to the usual commercial fragrances. A lovely citrus wood combo. This would be nice to wear on a summer evening. It would be perfect for wearing in the office. Feminine but to be respected. As you would expect the orange is very evident from the word go. It adds a freshness and sweetness to the orchid and wood notes. I love the orange, orchid, patch, sandalwood combo unfortunately with the pepper becoming more and more evident on the dry down. Tbh I think all the pepper towards the end is too much and prevents it becoming a love for me. I dont find it very masculine at all. Moderate sillage and longevity.

Very nice but very masculine on me...androgynous at best.

I'm not getting any pepper at all which is a shame since I love peppery notes. I can't quite place what makes it so masculine to me. Maybe the orange with rosewood? I think I might give this one to my hubs. It will likely smell much nicer on him.

Not a bad scent at all - just not as feminine a fragrance as I usually enjoy. ;)

not my cup of tea :( the pepper in the top notes is very strong and chemical... it isn´t a bad composition, but it didn´t work together. for me it´s a very simple and absolutely unimpressive scent, very masculine, but nothing special - it´s like a simple cheap man´s perfume. Probably it would be better with some warm and sweet accord there (vanilla, amber?).
not bad got it at a bargin price a great winter scent reminds me of angel
You see ,it's comments like the one before me that make me feel completely useless on this fabulous website. Fabulous reviews like the one before me....:) spot on!

Ahhh... tha' Paradox of Presence... a Presence revealed thru an androgynous tapestry of spicy/warm fragrance notes. So many folks getting hung on whether it's masculine or feminine/male or female/blahblah... just getover your sweetself & enjoy tha' ride. Lotta curves w/ this ride, presenting a playful drydown that travels from good2better w/ excellent sillage/longevity. But one needs 2 respect one's unique individual chemistry... one of the cool traits of an excellent juice is its capacity for smelling different on different folks. Masculine, or feminine?... Yes! For it is a classique of both animals, & on some will be masculine w/ a feminine touch, & on some, feminine w/ a masculine touch. That's a goodthing... we're actually created tha' same way... & yet...UNIQUE, ladies & gentlemen. But a deeper & more interesting paradox emerges... this one is Strong&Subtle. The wonderful scents of orchid, manderin, pepper, sandalwood, vanilla, patchouli, & the others, display suble fairness of 'presence', without knockin' you down, like commercial scents these days. For instance, when you cook, you don't want the ingredient 2 stand out, like, man... that's CURRY... you want it 2 blend into a design that cues you into, hmmm, nice taste, smooth flavour. Scents should do tha' same. I don't care 2 hear, "isn't that vanilla?" Perish tha' thought, though many of today's lackluster/losers are like that. You just want it 2 subtlely intice, the different notes, in harmony w/ each other. And remember, you DON'T want folks 2 SMELL you , before they SEE you; w/ a keeper juice, it should be a 'less is more' dynamic, if it has decent sillage/longevity. Enjoy the Paradox of Presence: Strong but subtle, playful but serious, aloof but intense... it may reflect your own Presence... hope so, for tha' sake of Surprise, Dearie ~

This is one of my power fragrances. When I go to the office and mean business, this is what I wear. Not too girly, just a tinge masculine and absolutely lovely; the perfect fragrance to go with a power suit.

I've worn this in the past being only "sweet" 19 (I'm 28 now) and felt so grown up :) It was a gift of my mom. She herself received it as a gift but wasn't really into it so lucky me!

I've ordered it again a few days ago and it finally arrived. It's soft and classy but edgy and fun at the same time. The perfect combination of feminine and masculine notes: peppery, woody, patch and a little flowers and fruit. Fresh and at the same time warm. I'm seeing a scheme here with my taste: I also love Chance, Dune... For me they also have these characteristics.

I've had Lovely by SJP as my signature for a very long time but from now on this will be it. I'm so happy to have this in my collection again and hope that they won't discon' it anytime soon!

Beautiful present from sweet veda! I love it. Was always imagining it similar with Roma by Laura Biagiotti and yes, they are - similar. Yet old formula of Roma is more heavy and substantional, while Présence d'une is more soapy-lightly-spiced more woody-orchids fragrance. Individuel has to be one of the most popular fragrance community scents of all time, and a perfume I got for the second time in 2025. What can I say except that for all of your fragrance enthusiasts who have been in this never-ending game for a long time, Individuel is a distant cousin of Joop! Homme, and a fragrance from which Creed’s Original Santal took heavy inspiration.

TOP NOTES
Upon the first spray and a couple of minutes until the top notes start to fade away, I get this delightful mix of lavender, juniper berries, spice, and a touch of pineapple. In my experience, the opening is relatively fresh and clean, but not plain – the fruit and spice give it an energising character.

HEART NOTES
After 5-10 minutes, the scent transitions to the heart (middle) phase. Here, the pineapple and big spice notes start to fade, leaving behind a blend of herbal and floral tones. Lavender stays the most prominent note, and we are introduced to orange blossom similar to the one found in the famous Nikos Sculpture. Compared to the top, the heart is cleaner and simpler. It’s almost like the fragrance “cools off” into a soapy lavender/vanilla laundry scent.

BASE NOTES
For me, the combination of raspberry, vanilla, and top-notch implementation of sandalwood really comes forward, giving a creamy, woody warmth along with fruity and comforting touches. The dry-down (base) has a warm, soft, and subtly sweet quality. It feels like a comfortable sweater or flannel shirt in scent form.

OVERALL
There is always a place in your perfume collection for a versatile, budget-friendly men’s scent that will surprise you with its pleasant character. It’s not a high-end niche masterpiece, but it doesn’t try to be. Instead, it delivers a warm, sweet-woody scent with a touch of fruity freshness. Highly recommended!

Montblanc Individuel, with its exquisite blend of scents, is a fantastic choice for office wear fragrance, offering a perfect balance of sophistication and subtlety that is bound to leave a lasting impression. This scent has the potential to garner you numerous compliments due to its unique and appealing aroma, which is neither too bold nor too understated, creating an ideal presence in a professional environment. However, it's important to note that while Montblanc Individuel exudes a delightful subtlety, the oak moss note, which is a prominent feature in its composition, can be a little overwhelming for some, occasionally overshadowing the more delicate components of the fragrance. I'd even say that the raspberry in this fragrance holds up incredibly well in this era of syrupy fruit-salad gourmands, and isn't nearly an offensive or cloying berry smell. Granted, it doesn't have the longevity or performance of a modern gourmand (and I wish they did an EDP just so I could smell it for longer) but it does have an moderate performance for an EDT that's a jack-of-all-trades and costs only £25 for 75ml!

Individuel is timeless, you may be able to discern it as an early-ish Y2K style of cologne due to it's strangeness when compared to the shower-gels, the spice-bombs, the gourmands - but it stands on its own as something reliable and suitable for most occasions; it's laid back, maybe a little playful, comforting and definitely an easy dumb reach.

Montblanc Individuel opens with a sharp hit of mint — almost like chewing on berry ice gum. It’s cool, sweet, and slightly playful with raspberry and lavender adding a fruity, aromatic touch. As it dries down, creamy sandalwood and vanilla come forward, giving it a soft, smooth base with hints of chocolate and spice.

This is absolutely a synthetic-smelling fragrance, but in a way that feels clean, modern, and approachable. While it may not be the most traditionally masculine scent, its slight femininity actually invites compliments. It’s a refreshing break from the usual bold men’s fragrances and offers a unique, easy-to-wear profile.

I was introduced to this by Jeremy Fragrance and I'm so glad, because it's great. I have never understood why it isn't more popular given its price tag, but I think it's one of the best fragrances for the money on the market.

After mowing through 2 full bottles of this stuff within the last year, with a 3rd one on the way, I can safely say that this is my favorite scent. I love it. It checks all of the boxes:

-It's unique, yet comforting. Raspberry, pineapple, dark chocolate, cinnamon, and vanilla notes make an appearance, yet none are overpowering.
-It works very well with my skin chemistry regardless of season.
-It's somehow fresh without going the usual citrus/aquatic route. I seriously dig the synthetic fresh linen smell in the opening.
-The longevity is perfect - about 7 to 8 hours. It lasts most of a workday but doesn't get into obnoxious territory.
-Speaking of work... this is a fragrance that won't get you sent to HR. I find it impossible to overspray.
-The price is right. $20-25 for a full bottle? Ok, there you go.
-High compliment factor. My wife loves it. Friends have randomly told me I smell good. I've even gotten 3 or 4 compliments from total strangers - something that has never happened before.
-For what it's worth, even the bottle design is awesome. Solid atomizer, too.

And as far as the Joop comparisons go... this ain't Joop. I'm not a Joop hater, but that's like comparing Sunny D to actual orange juice. Yeah, they have a couple similarities, but once you get past the superficials, you'll see it's not even close.

In conclusion, my only complaint about Individuel is that it doesn't come in a larger bottle. I would buy a Gatorade cooler full of this stuff if Montblanc sold it as such.

I have amassed quite a wardrobe of fragrances, but I always find myself coming back to Montblanc Individuel. It’s consistently a great compliment-getter and feels uniquely well-rounded. I haven't tried Creed Original Santal yet, but I can absolutely see why it's often said that Creed took inspiration from Individuel.

When I first wore it, I didn’t immediately notice the chocolate note—but once it was pointed out, I couldn’t un-smell it. Initially, I was struck more by a spicy lavender accord, blended with what I can best describe as a fire-roasted pineapple nuance. It's an intriguing and unexpected combination that keeps it interesting.

That said, it can be overwhelming on an active summer day, not just because of the scent profile but also due to its impressive longevity and projection. In an air-conditioned office, it's manageable, but for more active or outdoor professions, it might come across as too forward or intrusive.

Still, I find Individuel to be classy, casual, distinctive, and a definite attention-getter. It stands out without trying too hard, striking a balance between being unique and approachable. It’s one of those rare fragrances that feels equally at home on a laid-back day or dressed up for an evening out.

Spraying top notes: I sense it intensively aromatic with fresh spicy, warm scents of lavender and cardamon. I also identify a slight citric smell - bergamot and citric notes. As time passed by, it became predominantly fruity and fresh transitioning to spicy notes.

At the heart, it became overwhelmingly floral and clean. Yet so, noticeable fruity/berry fragrances. I couldn't identify any trace of woody notes. Maybe slightly, indistinguishable from floral and fruity scents. At best I do not have the sensitivity to feel them.

In conclusion, I hold that Montblanc Individuel is a very discrete, low-profile and intimate fragrance (low sillage). It is wearable in the spring and fall day-light seasons, considering how fruity and floral it is. It fits perfectly at work, given its intimacy and freshness. However, it is a very particular fragrance, which means that you might like it or hate it (I like it, my wife don't).

Blind bought since it was cheap, and I would say that this is not really a safe blind buy. The first time I wore this, I absolutely hated it. All I could smell is dryer sheet, because it does in fact smell like a straight up dryer sheet fresh out the box. It's not necessarily a bad smell, since it's essentially a clean laundry smell, but not really attractive to my tastes, as it was overly powdery and fresh linen smell. Maybe even a bit like fabreeze? If you want to make sure everyone knows that your shirt is clean because you just pulled it out of the dryer, this is the stuff for you.

Once I tried it a couple more times, I was able to look past the dryer sheet smell and pick up some of the other notes, although I think there are waaaay too many notes given and it's really a pretty simple scent. On the dry down, you definitely get the sweeter raspberry smell as well as some vanilla and chocolate. A slight hint of amber and musk (very slight) gives it some masculinity. There are some florals there, mainly I would say lavender lending to the laundry smell, and maybe some sandalwood, but I wouldn't call this a woody fragrance by any means. Performance is decent, but not anything to write home about. Once again, not a safe blind buy in my opinion, as the powdery linen smell is not for everyone, but I do think this is a good one for if you want a generic, non-citrus, fresh fragrance for the daytime or maybe bedtime.

Personally, I would give it probably an honest, right down the middle 5/10, as I could take it or leave it. It's not great, but it's not necessarily bad. I won't be buying another bottle because it's not really to my tastes, but it is kind of a unique smell amongst freshies, since it lacks the citrus and aquatic notes that are so common. If smelling like a dryer sheet placed on top of a slice of raspberry cheesecake sounds interesting to you, maybe pick it up to try since it is cheap and intriguing.

I have two perspectives on Individuel. First, I think for a $15 - $24 price tag, it's great and smells better than most people around you throughout the day. Especially when most men in the US only wear a fragrance for special occasions. It lasts a full work day even with heavy perspiration.

The second perspective is, "how much are you willing to pay to smell good for yourself?" I think everyone should wear fragrances for themselves, not others. If you want a good smelling fragrance, buy one you love, not cause it's inexpensive.

Anyway, the scent opens with old school sharpness like white peppery mint notes if that makes sense. But the middle and dry down are sweet. Take joop homme tone down with a hint of vanilla and light powdery musk in the back. It leaves a noticeable scent trail in office settings and if you're trying to be discovered this could work in highly active or professional settings. You'll know if it's for you after your first full wear. I would recommend you definitely try it.

This is an odd fragrance. First sprays I couldn't smell it on me at all, very slight "Clean sheets" kind of smell when burying my nose on the skin, but SO said it's "good". I was kind of disappointed thinking I got a dud and performance was awful. Gave it a few more "warning" sprays in the air and let it sit for a night.

It matured and showed it's colours in full brightness just overnight. It's a very clean smelling, fresh laundry like smell, with strong raspberry note. A clean-sweet combo of two. "Clean fresh laundry" note, which I award to Lavender, starts slightly chemically, like a laundry detergent, but not as bad as some people described. It settles down fast to powdery clean smell. Equally strong is the Raspberry note - those two are the main notes here. It's potent but inoffensive. Smooth powderiness of White Florals ties it all together, making for a pleasant smelling, inoffensive but good-performing fragrance. Sinking my nose into skin I get a hint of Vanilla, and a bit of Mint, but none of the other listed notes.

I definitely get the Joop! resemblance - it smells like a less potent and cloyingly sweet, but more fresh, mature, and office friendly version of it. Performance is similarly strong - it projects "average" for a couple of hours, and the sits close to skin for the rest of the day. Even after shower I can clearly smell it on my skin - it has some staying power!

Like the aforementioned Joop!, this does smell a bit out of fashion, but is a good fragrance overall. Definitely an easy and flexible wear. I'd pick it over Joop! as well. 50/50 for a blind buy - I'd lean towards safe but if you're unsure about if you like sweet fragrances, probably should sample it first.

Also love the tin bottle - saves so much space!

First impressions. I have no problem with funky smells and I'm quite fond of animalic musks and all sorts of intrigues, but this one initially almost made me gag. The reason for it seems to be an overdose of a certain laundry musk. It's a clean musk, but comes with an overbearingly mineral chlorine note that smells like something straight from a chemist's lab. Underneath that, a cloyingly sweet, yet strangely flat pineapple smell. I get no raspberry, but there is some mint. It's vaguely similar to other Montblanc fragrances with the Aventus/Fierce-inspired pineapple theme. But this one is a scrubber for me, and I'm getting a mild headache now. It baffles me how this could be perceived as a dumb reach freshie. And no, it's not similar to Joop! Homme.

-----

Later impressions. It seems to be a fragrance that needs some acclimatization. After my nose got used to the chlorine note, it actually appears kind of wearable. It's still probably a fragrance that's not meant to be smelled up close. The sillage is mineralic musky clean and fruity, seems to work in the current summer heat at least. But up close, I still get an impression of a cleaning agent with bleach that's covering up a bluntly sour and weirdly sweet note... Not exactly vomit, but for some reason, this was the first association. It's probably a passing association anyway, but I stand by my claim that this is not a blind buy safe fragrance by today's standards or a good idea for a gift. There are much safer options for conveying this kind of intense freshness. But at least I'm beginning to get the idea behind this fragrance.

#115 in my "Tour de Fragrance" I like this. I'm used to being disappointed by the weakness of Mont Blanc formulations, but this is going 3+hours, and at this price respraying during the day is not a problem. There's enough powder here to keep the fruitiness from being too much. Combine fresh sheets at the Four Seasons with a fruit basket in the room. It's clean, and crisper than I was expecting. This is a no brainer blind buy, 100% office safe.

Fragancia delicada y femenina ok para uso diario laboral.
Según el vendedor prometía larga duración/excelente sillage. No me resultó. Como mucho dura 2 hs. Y el sillage imperceptible.

I get sharp clashing white florals on opening - I thought this was a failed blind buy, but to my great surprise and delight after 30mins it settles into a warm, delicately sweet, lightly spiced, musky blended flower potion. I layer this with a lemony citrus perfume to tame the opening.

Exactly what I wanted the original to smell like!
This is a such a feel good perfume and all of the notes work harmoniously. The top notes seem to last until drydown and envelope the rest of the notes. It works so well from beginning to end.
For me, this delivered on all fronts- bottle, scent, projection and sillage. I've been so tired of picking apart perfumes and having a note or two disrupt a scent. With this one I just sprayed and enjoyed. It's lovely.

I'm not sure what's wrong with me but all I wanna do is bathe myself in this. But I don't like ANY floral rose?

I've tried three new frags, this being one. Frustratingly close to the skin, barely a bean of sillage, such a shame as the notes are not bad

I always loved sweet, powdery perfumes and this one I simply fell in love with at the first sniff! It was a blind buy - no regrets! Rosey-vanilla with a hint of jasmine makes me feel sexy and romantic at the same time. Will be buying it again!

I was really surprised with how much I liked this - I don’t usually like very “floral” or “woody” fragrances at all. Lady Emblem Elixir on me opens with a lovely fruity freshness, the lychee and mandarin is delicious. Then it drys down to a lovely softly sweet rose with a touch of vanilla, it’s really gorgeous. I can’t stop sniffing my wrist. I don’t get any woodiness or powder at all. I don’t know about projection but longevity on my skin was 2-3 hours.

***Update***Bought myself a bottle and I love it. The rose is fruity and gentle, the lychee is more a floral lychee than the synthetic blast in scents like La Nuit Tresor, and the dry down is a lovely soapy rose and vanilla. There is a bit of an alcohol blast at the beginning, especially if you spray it super close on to skin/clothing, better to give it a little room of a couple of inches.

A very generic warm (but not sickly sweet) floral - I get rose, jasmine and vanilla. It is lovely, but there's no 'hook' or 'catch' that makes it stand out. Ok longevity and sillage, but I was expecting more from an EDP. The bottle and stopper are beautiful, but the fragrance itself is not impressive enough for me to want to re-buy.

It's nice, not outstanding, just nice. Good quality of course.
A Rose, slightly peppery, slightly boozy, slightly sweet.
I wouldn't call it an Elixir though.

The bottle on the other hand is stunning!

I never really care about bottles just as long as they're good quality and I do prefer the minimalistic ones like Narciso Rodriguez, but I had to comment on this one.

The bottle is a work of art and the stopper is glass.

Guess I'm keeping it for the bottle, not the juice :)

Nice one. Peppery rose with a hint of vanilla when opening, and the dry down is a biiiit masculine due to the patchouli. Long-lasting, moderate sillage. It reminds me of many others... it could use a little more personality.
Top notes are very pleasant, but after a while it is hard to define. Not bad, just strange.

Well i bought this today and I own Lady Emblem too. It is a very smooth eau de parfum, I think that the word elixir is too much for this one. Rose is dominant in the beginning and a soapy feel from the middle till the end. IMO you can actually smell the roses better in this one then in the original version.
The base in this one brings out the roses better. It' s a very feminine soft floral scent that stays close to the skin, it's classy and sweet not vanillic sweet. I believe it would have being much better if it was a bit stronger. I expect more power from an "elixir". Overall a quite nice edp with character for the flowery kind of lovers!

7/10

It doesn't smell anything like Chrome. Maybe a hint at the beggining.

@leroystanks A fragrance can have the same palette of essences but in different proportions. As you can see, the order of the ingredients listed is different for both Individuel and Individuel Tonic, so it is not a "copy-paste".

I love this one. It was a blind buy and I couldn't be happier, especially given the very reasonable price point. This has a very fresh green soapy accord but with some woody almost nutty density and amber that give it lots of character. It's very masculine and traditional but it doesn't really smell like anything else I've come across. It's suitable for all seasons and I find that it lasts longer on my skin that most of my other Montblanc colognes. Funny, I bought the original Individuel after loving this one first and I don't like it at all. The two have very little in common with the original having a weird off-putting minty and synthetic smell to me. Couldn't be happier with this one, and the icing on the cake is that it has the most attractive bottle in my collection: super handsome emerald colored glass and sleek wedge shaped flask design make this one a work of art.

Montblanc Individuel Tonic is a fresh and invigorating take on the original Individuel, offering a lighter, more vibrant twist. It opens with a zesty burst of grapefruit and bergamot, creating an energetic and uplifting start. The heart introduces a subtle floral touch with lavender, balanced by a clean, soapy undertone that feels crisp and refined. The base of white musk and woody notes provides a soft, comforting finish, making it versatile and easy to wear. Perfect for daytime or casual occasions, this fragrance is ideal for those who enjoy a fresh, clean scent with a modern edge. While it may not have the heaviest projection or longevity, its simplicity and refreshing character make it a great choice for everyday wear.

Rating is 7.5/10
A light, approachable, and versatile fragrance for casual or warm-weather use.

It’s hard to take this site seriously when all the information about this fragrance – release date, perfumer, note pyramid – is completely wrong. In fact, the notes are just copy/pasted from the original Individuel.

What are we even doing here? How is this listing up for this long with no corrections made?

This is like "Raucousdaucus" says below: the notes here are wrong, they're probably right but incomplete in wiki. To my own knowledge and perception I'd describe this as:

Top: Pineapple, Bergamot, Cardamom, Coriander
Mid: Clary Sage (strong!), Lavender, Orange Blossom, clear woods (ISO-E)
Base: Ambroxan (overdose!), Sandalwood, Musk, Moss

It is easy to wear, performs average, it's an all-season creamy-soapy modern masculine fougere. It reminds me of Drakkar Noir intense, but sweeter and fruitier and way less mossy. The presentation is like the OG Individuel, if you have that one, you will want to get this just to place it alongside on your shelf.

Then again, the biggest issue is, where's the tonic, Dude? Nothing lactonic, fizzy, nor any juniper here. The herbal undertone that dominates the mid is the sweetish transparent clary sage, not anything strong and manly like spruce, fir, pine. The moss here is barely noticeable. The whole formula feels soapy, tamed, diluted, restrained, obedient, workplace compliant, but the Ambrocenide amount here can be offensive to the nostrils. This could be the perfume for a nice foot powdered deodorant. The base lasts forever on clothes.

I dig the comparisons to Chrome, they're both transparent and light enough, but this has no citrus top/mid neither any relation to D&G K as no spices are really present here, only mild herbal undertones. It strongly reminds me of the herbal dryness of Cretan mountain tea. A nice to have and not at all overpriced product for any occasion really.
Update - A beautiful and effective silage wafts away from this.

Amber/Ambroxan BOMB. What’s are you all smelling here? People are easily influenced by colors. This is barely green. It’s a ton of laundry musk (I don’t mind) with some soapy aldehydes and florals and then a nuclear amber bomb. I love green scents; This could’ve smelled like parsley and tide and I would have been content with the blind buy. But that screechy amber means I’m giving it away or tossing it. What a lazy composition. BOO!

I no longer trust the notes on fragrantica. I think wikiparfum has it right.

This is really nice. It's elegant and well blended. Slighty

I really think this is one of the nicest recent green/Summer perfumes to come out.
