Saw this in Home Bargains for £22, checked Fragrantica and thought it was worth a try. Wow, it's even better that I expected. Lovely fresh, green fragrance. I even bought a second bottle.

First Pass - I viscerally dislike this. I recognize the scent but it eludes my grasp. Everything is muddled together, it's musty and spoiled somehow... I can't put my finger on it.

1 Hour Later - It hit me like a ton of bricks. This is unmistakably lime, but rancid lime. The lime that has been on the shelf or in the fridge too long and the green skin is blotchy tan and yellow. This is exactly what that smells like

24 hours later, I finally get the tonic, or the juniper. Not freshly opened tonic water, this is soured, oxidized tonic water that has sat on the bar overnight (garnished with an old lime wedge)

I do not like this at all. But I have to admit, now that I've identified the smell, it's kind of like a car crash. It's a mess, but it's so interesting I'm lured back

Generally I find bottles superfluous. A poor bottle or a cheap cap detract from the joy of application, but I have yet to find an elegant bottle capable of uplifting a malodorous concoction

That said, this vessel is beautiful. Emerald green, thin, cat-eye oval body, collared with a shiny metal epaulet and topped with a heavy, rounded metal cap

***Scents, like tastes, are subjective. Wear what you like***

Superb fragrance. The presentation, like all Montblanc fragrances is great and the bottle is to die for, easily the best on my shelf, It's heavy and the green makes it look like it contains Kryptonite, the upper part and the lid are metal. I'd use it as a hip flask if I could!!

The fragrance is very green and the opening is a little underwhelming, but after an hour or so the fragrance starts to open up. I definitely get the Geranium and the there's a damp mossy accord there also, its got great sillage and you know its leaving a trail. It's cheap, at £22 for 75ml you can use it liberally, and you need to for performance. It's an uncomplicated and very clean green fragrance with good presence. This is one where the bottle really matches the scent. I can only imagine its been given the Individual moniker because it shares the same bottle, but that's the only similarity. There poles apart in DNA, the original Individual was very sweet to my mind and a tad unisex, nothing like Individual Tonic. It should have been given its own name really, because it totally deserves it.

What's odd is I notice this fragrance dates from 2018, but its the first time I've seen it in any shops, and it seems to be everywhere now? I'll certainly stock up on it at this price, personally I think its the best and most original Montblanc aftershave I've ever used.

First of all, I don't detect at least half of the notes listed here, so either it's MASTERFULLY blended for a budget fragrance or someone is lying, lol.

In any case, this is a very pleasant aromatic freshie. It harkens back to the early 2000s a bit with a heavy juniper berry note in the opening and a glut of synthetic florals and fruits backing it up. I do agree with the comparisons to D&G K although this one is less dense and to me, actually smells more pleasing. I would say it's a great substitute for the D&G for that reason, especially if you can get it from a rack store. I won't be running out to pick it up as it's just not very interesting to me, but I think it'd be a great entry-level fragrance for just about any age range. Spring and fall recommended, I don't think it'd work very well in the high heat.

The Mint, The Rosemary and the Pineapple to me are the main stars of the opening to this amusingly strange perfume. Is VERY VERY VERY GREEN and herbal. Takes a little time to get used to it..... Do I LOVE IT?? No .... But I don't hate it either. I do like it and I can wear this to any outdoorsy occassion anytime. The sad part is it's projection and longevity.... JUST LIKE ALL MONTBLANC FRAGS. I was hoping (since its an INDIVIDUEL FLANKER) that would last as the OG does but I was dissappointed. Solution??? Spray on Clothes and 12 to 14 times.

Tonic doesn’t develop a ton but as time goes on that minty,watery freshness dies down and it becomes more dry while retaining that green,soapy freshness ! In the drydown I smell a lot of ISO E super mixed with green soapy freshness ! This is very reminiscent of an Irish Spring body wash I smelled recently.

(Scents that to my nose it’s similar to are Azzaro Chrome,Swiss Army Classic, and Aromatic Touch by Rochas)

I enjoy soapy scents so I do enjoy this but it’s a casual soapy and not on the same level as Prada style scents

Performance is average as it lasts 5-6 hours with good projection for an hour but then dies down quickly and you’re left with just a scent bubble that only people close you will smell. For that reason it’s good for work if you let it die down after an hour as that first hour it’s pretty strong

Overall rating -7 out of 10 ! I like this scent profile so I do enjoy it but it’s not my favorite soapy smell

This fragrance has been unfairly dismissed by some YouTube reviewers - who should know better :) - as being generic and generally 'meh' and pleasant at best. I disagree. I think it's quite a sophisticated versatile uplifting scent with good quality if slightly synthetic ingredients that result in excellent performance, longevity (7 hours +) and sillage - at least in autumn which is when I've tried it. However I would be comfortable wearing it in any season and I suspect it would perform just as well. It's fresh and fruity with an interesting green herbal backdrop where for me the pineapple, rosemary and moss stand out. I find it characterful (certainly not generic) and definitely masculine, and would suit any age but in my view leans towards the more mature (say 30+). Works extremely well as a casual daytime fragrance, although it can work just as well in the office and smart attire. Gorgeous packaging, and a special love for that striking emerald green bottle!

This is a surprising blind-buy win for me as I'm used to Montblanc fragrances being beautifully packaged and interesting but lacking performance - which this one certainly doesn't. Full marks for being fresh without resorting to aquatic/watery/blue notes. To my best knowledge, I've never smelt the OG Individuel to compare it with, but taken at face value, this new edition is very good and I'm certainly not disappointed.

So, being a fan of the original Individuel, seeing it as the Joop! Homme for the more refined man, I have been waiting to get my hands on this for a while since it first popped up, unannounced. It is still currently unavailable in the UK from UK suppliers however is available on FragranceX as of the date of this review.

Onto the fragrance, it's not got much of the Individuel DNA, its pleasant enough, but I would struggle to distinctively pick this up on someone like I would the original. Its got similar performance to the original in both longevity and sillage. The only link I find it has to the original is that almost dusty freshness mixed with fruit, the original was raspberry where as this has pineapple, which is less of the fruity kind and more of the exterior woody pine and leaves of the pineapple. All in all, its worth having at the price you can probably get it for in the states. But the £40 I paid for it? No, not worth it.

Just an amazing fragrance. A real pity they discontinued it, but that's just what they do with good products, apparently. One of the absolute best men's fragrances of all time, hands down, and not an overstatement. It has been extremely downplayed and gatekept. The scent is best summed up, to me, as a cross between A&F Fierce Intense (another discontinued banger that I urge everyone to buy while you can) and JPG Scandal Absolu. It has that airy, fresh, slightly marine vibe in the air like Fierce (not just the vibe, it does smell very similar), but its sweetness is distinctly similar to Scandal Absolu with a tiny hint of watermelon Jolly Rancher lol. What an incredibly unique and brilliant composition that works so beautifully. Seems to perform pretty dang good by all accounts, too. My skin is pretty dry and I go nose deaf to a lot of things easily, but it is still pretty durable by my standards. This is also an incredibly versatile fragrance for a sweeter scent, for sure. It really is all occasions. If you are a money tree, then don't even think about not buying this if you can find it. I don't even want to say what I payed for 5 bottles. I haven't tried the other Legends (besides Spirit which I do not like particularly), but hopefully the EDP is a worthy alternative to this, because I'm not sure I can advise paying over 150-160usd for a bottle of this unless you love Fierce DNA and are a man of extremely few fragrances and just must have the best. This is one of the best, and ludicrously underrated on here score wise at 4.25. Should be 4.55+. Unfortunately, it would be very hard to sample, but at least if you take the leap to buy it for that cheap, you can resell it for more at least. To be completely honest, I personally prefer Fierce Intense (which I usually layer with normal Fierce) just because I am not the world's biggest fan of the sweeter scents on myself. I like to stay on the slightly fresher side as far as what I wear, and Fierce Intense maintains more of the Fierce DNA throughout and performs well. It is slightly sweet, but not on the fruity side the way Legend Intense is. That's just a personal preference, though. The base of Legend Intense really starts to smell exactly like Scandal Absolu to me, though, in the dry down, which I also love (but a little fruitier, as Ihave said). So awful to see things like this go away, but if anyone knows something that is a dead ringer to this, shoot me a dm.

That out of the way, I really wish we could hijack the “r word” from its historical use and redefine it to be a more emphatic alternative to describe something or someone that is intentionally or blatantly irrational or idiotic, and therefore deserving of some form of hassling.

My initial impression on the first wearing is good...but not great. Before I get into it, my 3.4oz bottle was bought second hand, almost full, but without the cap. There's a slight chance it has changed inside the bottle, although I don't think it's old enough for that. Now that that's out of the way:

The review below mine describes the scent well, however, I disagree that this is essential. This feels like the perfumer tried to connect the original Legend to Creed Aventus (not exactly, but in the ballpark). While the original definitely smells just like A&F Fierce, Intense smells much less similar, only slightly so. Imagine a toned down Fierce (basically, the modern formula) with added depth of fruits. This one sits close to the skin, unlike original Legend and Fierce. Reviewers here are raving about compliments, but you would also get similar compliments wearing original Legend. If you're looking for a smoother version of a Fierce clone (which isn't as loud as silver cap Fierce), then Legend Intense would be suitable. But, I don't see this being worth the high prices of a discontinued scent. You'd be better off with a niche frag from PDM or Jo Malone, for example, if you're willing to spend over $100 on this. It goes without saying that Explorer is really solid, comparable to this, and closer to Aventus. There's a reason why Legend, Legend Spirit and Individuel are still around and several other MB scents were discontinued: sales. Legend Intense is a good one, but not too much more than that. I'll update this review if I'm moved by more wearings and inspiration.

Update: After wearing it more, it's the same simple verdict: a richer, less-loud version of Fierce, with a hint of Aventus.

It's what its name suggests: a sweeter, denser, stronger version of the original. One of my all-time favorites. I get compliments almost every time I wear it, especially out at night. Great projection and longevity on me. I often say that any man looking to strip down his collection to sure-fire winners could get by with this, Aventus, GIT, Azzaro Pour Homme, Rive Gauche, and Bleu de Chanel Parfum. They meet all of my needs. Everything else in my collection is just for fun and variety.

I wish that Mont Blanc had not decided to discontinue this gem. I suppose they're banking on building out the Explorer line. If the original is any indication, they have a long way to go to make that decision worthwhile.

A less refined version of Fierce believe it or not. It's not intense by any means and it smells only marginally better than the regular Legend. Department store tonka-amber sweetness over a bed of some ''modern woods''. I don't get any fruit accords in here and frankly I'm surprised somehow pineapple and red apple are listed as the main notes according to others. It smells alright just as a normal ''cologne'' would. Nothing remotely interesting here.

Sits fairly close to the skin and lasts a couple hours. Honestly there are much better options out there. This could be an okay scent for a starter, but unless you're really a fan of the Fierce DNA, this is a pass. And do yourself a favor and don't fall for any outrageous asking prices since it's been discontinued.

Though my tastes in fragrances have evolved to more daring, less mass-appealing niche frags since I’ve started a couple of years ago, i still got to have this one in my collection and wear it regularly.
It’s a very good “dumb” reach... yes, the apple/pineapple notes are a bit too synthetic. But it could be worse and headache-inducing (hello, Dior Sauvage), but the overall smell AND the performance is fantastic!
It reminds me a bit of Bond n 9 Scent Of Peace for him at times. Not that they smell the same, but they’re family. It might a bit too youthful and not really complex to the trained nose, but it does the job : it smells good, it lasts, it projects and has sillage... for the price I think is a very good product. And the ladies love it lol... not that I wear them to impress the opposite sex, but I get random compliments every now and then (this might be in my top 5 most complimented fragrances). The sweetness of the fruity-vanillic fragrance is really loved by the women around me, mrs Moonchild especially :)
Compared to other pineapple scents, it’s not as good or quality as Aventus, it is the same ballpark as Scent Of peace for him (just lacking the more upscale quality... but it could as well be a flanker) and IMHO it is better than Sauvage in any category.
If you don’t like sweet fragrances à la One Million or Invictus, you might avoid it., if you do, this belongs in your wardrobe.
Scent 8/10 - not the most sophisticated, a bit too sweet to some, you can not like it, but you can’t say it’s a bad perfume. Juvenile at times? Yes. Bad smelling? No.
Longevity 8/10 - no powerhouse, but close enough. Last 8+ hours on me. And far from being a skin scent.
Projection 9/10 - it builts a fragrance bubble around you. It can be smelled up to 3-4h 4-5 feet away. Fills up a room within the first hour.
Sillage 9/10 - nice scent trail for 2 to 3 hours. A head turner.

Overall 8,5/10. BUT I’m afraid there are bad news ... I haven’t seen Legend Intense recently in our local Sephoras and the like for the past couple of weeks.. is it being discontinued? Reformulated? Who knows.

Edit : I’ve just read some reviews complaining about the performance... that’s weird to me. Maybe a reformulation? Or confusion with the original Legend? It’s is actually one of my best performing designer scents!

Intense is a cardamom bomb up top, with the pineapple and jasmine giving it a spicy floral accord. After about an hour or so, it dries down to a warm apple with wisps of cardamom and a powdery amber. I get very little woods until it dries down completely (2 hour mark) and then the cedar really shines through. Lasts for about 6 hours after that as it gradually becomes a skin scent. Reminds me kind of like Rocky Mountain He Wood by DeSquared at the base but less peppery.

If you love cardamom and spicy woody frags, you will really dig it like I do. I can see why some say it reminds them of soap or shampoo, but the cardamom and woods really pulls this together.

Good potency, decent projection, longevity, and sillage. Would recommend as a beginner fragrance for men who fancy scents that aren't too generic.

I think spraying under the shirt on chest is good as the scent stays on my clothes longer than skin. Still very decent performance imo and a fantastic scent.

I've owned this for a few months, gave it a first proper wearing today since the brutal heatwave has subsided here in France. I have been wearing the fantastic Legend Spirit on some warmer days this summer too.

Intense is closer to the original of which I have a sample than to Spirit for sure, all three of them are superb. I'm still undecided on Legend Night though but what an excellent fragrance line this is so far, real top quality from Montblanc including the fantastic bottles!

For me the red apple note really stands out here and although I'm not usually the biggest fan of apple notes (perhaps sometimes with cinnamon in a seasonal frag though) I really like it here, it's perfectly blended with the other notes to create something special in my opinion, it definitely seems a reworking of Legend rather than the exact same scent intensified.

Of the three Legend frags I have this is the sweetest, most fruity and least 'fresh' but it is not cloying or heavy, performance is above average without being beast mode, decent longevity too. This is a versatile scent that could easily be signature scent worthy. This stuff oozes quality that would make many far more expensive fragrance houses blush.

My gf was looking for a father's day gift for her dad, so I offered her my bottle of Legend since I don't use it often, and he previously mentioned that he enjoyed the smell.

The funny thing is, that once he sprayed it on in front of her, it reawakened her affinity for the scent and she immediately ordered me to repurchase it. LoL. Darn.

As a compromise, we stopped by at Sephora and I said that I would let her choose her favourite men's frag out of everything they had, and that I would pick it up that day. Secretly, I was just trying to avoid buying Legend again. But can you guess what she chose??? Yeah. Legend Intense. Ugh.

Tom Ford, Hermes, Atelier, Dior, and she chose a Legend flanker. Ok. Well, just to have an objective opinion, I sprayed a test strip with Legend Intense, and another with the 2011 formulation of La Nuit - a stunner to be sure - and politely approached an SA at Sephora with the question, "On a guy, would you prefer this one, or this one?"

A moment later, she replies - this one. Legend Intense. Hmmmmm. Ok. I thanked her for her opinion and walked over to the other side of the store and asked a slightly more attractive SA. This one, or this one? The answer came even faster - this one. Legend Intense.

At that moment, I think my eyebrows disappeared into my hairline because she gave me a quizzical look. On the outside, I was aware of myself smiling and giggling, but on the inside I was melting. Devastated. Three girls had just destroyed my self-righteous illusion.

But WHY Legend Intense?, I asked. The response - it's fresher and less spicy. She also asked me if it was Legend. I told her it was Legend Intense and she smiled. Yeah. Apparently EVERY girl in the store knows about Legend and loves it. Ahhhh, to be YOUNG again...

So that's it. I can't argue with the results. I came up with a cunning plan to get rid of my bottle of Legend, and ended up buying its much sweeter brother. True, I've grown to appreciate the scent a little more over the past few months, but I still wouldn't take it over something like Ultra Male or even Lacoste Style in Play - both fruity and both enjoyable.

Whatever. Women love it, and so it has a place in my collection. A dumb reach if nothing else. And in this case, I'll quote CoachRob619 - "Depending on what the ladies say, determines what I spray." Peace.

So eventhough I mentioned (like everyone) that this smells exactly like Apollo, I finally decided to grow a pair and get myself a sample ANYWAY, just so I could make a more objective assessment of this frag.

After all, my gf convinced me to get a bottle of Legend despite my initial objections, and that worked out alright. PS - I still don't care too much for the smell, but people seem to like me more when I wear it, so TS.

To preface this, I finally got rid of all my Axe Deo sprays last year to cut down on aerosols, but I DID manage to hang onto one - my favourite. Can you guess which one? Yeah.

So here we go - off the top it's sweet, fruity and creamy. Pineapple - unmistakable. (Phony) apple - yep. Tonka - yes sir. Pleasant - yes. Creamy stuff.
And then what's left of the alcohol disappears and we start to get sweeter and sweeter...and sweeter...

And then after about an hour, that sweetness hits a crescendo, only to hang on for the duration of the scent. And for me, that's the deal-breaker. It's just too sickeningly sweet. Maybe it's the synthetic-ness of the sweetness, I don't know, but to me, it's nauseating. Dan (MyMickers) was right on. I could only wear this twice before it made me feel...well...dizzy.

A side-by-side with the original Legend CLEARLY reveals Legend to be the "hollow" predecessor of Legend Intense. The base is still there in "Intense", but the sweetness and (rich) fruitiness is cranked up to 11. And THAT's why I prefer the original. It's tamer, it's lamer, but it makes me less sick. And since I'm the one who gets to smells ME most often, I'll pass on this one.

So there you have it - believe the reviews - it's really a denser, richer, and sweeter version of Apollo (which is a pleasant enough frag) but it's just way too... And BTW, 5/5 women I asked about Legend Intense also prefer the original Legend. Heck, it's cheaper too.

Montblanc Legend Intense Review:

This fragrance opens up with a very pleasant pineapple note. It then leads into a mid that's dominated by a spicy red apple smell. This is all held together by a soft tonka bean note in the base. Despite the fact that the notes are completely different, this does smell very similar to Fierce by Abercrombie & Fitch. So much so that if you own one, you probably wouldn't care to own the other. I personally like the way this one achieves it smell a little bit better. It's a sweeter, less in your face take on the Fierce scent we all know.

This is a pretty well-rounded and inoffensive scent that doesn't really seem all that "Intense" to me. This works much better as a casual fragrance that you can wear without having to give it much thought. That's not a negative. After all, there are probably times when all of us want something a bit lighter to wear. It's just something you should know going in. I think this one will appeal mostly to those of you in your 20's, who are looking for a versatile and easy to like fragrance.

If you're looking for an upgrade from the Fierce smell, I would definitely check out Platinum Egoiste by Chanel. It achieves the masculine smell these fragrances go for, but it accomplishes it with a much classier approach. Still, Legend Intense is a solid fragrance that I'm happy to have in my collection.

Best Age Group- 20's

I figured I'd add my thoughts of "Legend Intense" more as a warning for people. I'm guessing many of you found your way to this fragrance because of its similarities to "A&F Fierce". As many have said, yes, "Legend" does strongly resemble "Fierce", but I believe at a significant cost.

This fragrance is MUCH more synthetic smelling than "Fierce", or at least A&F's current offering of it. The synthetic smell isn't only found in the opening, but throughout the entire life of the fragrance.

My favorite aspect of "Fierce" is the dry-down. I like to smell it at close range on a shirt or on my hand. It is absolutely fantastic. But with "Legend Intense", it definitely isn't the same.

I've noticed fragrances that project louder typically have more of a synthetic aspect to them. Maybe this is why it is so prevalent with "Legend Intense". I can easily tell that in regards to projection, "Legend Intense" will outperform "Fierce". I'm also guessing that someone who smells "Legend" from a distance won't receive much of the synthetic aspects, and also believe it is "Fierce".

Just bear in mind; I still think on scent alone "Fierce" beats out "Legend" by a mile. It just has a higher quality vibe, and is much more sexy. However, I've also gained a lower tolerance for synthetics as I've expanded my collection.

I bought this as a cheaper, better performing version of "Fierce". Unfortunately, it only gets halfway there. The scent is inferior, but the projection is better.

Finally made a blind buy on MBLI and for me, this is probably the best over-all fragrance in my collection. The pineapple top notes are wonderful and remind me of Aventus, just not as smoky. In the dry down the other notes above come into play. Longevity is pretty good at 5 hrs and I'll wear this year round.

Playfulness and masculinity. Not only has this fragrance managed to balance the two, it does both exceptionally well while many others have failed to strike the right balance. Its ephemeral opening exudes a very fresh and playful tonka/apple/pineapple trio. The dry down introduces a strong sense of masculinity with the smell of an ashy fire. This is not the fire pit kids at camp would throw styrofoam cups into smell. Think of yourself sitting in front of a fireplace with a relative smoking a cherry cigar next to you. The drydown, as great as it is, does not project very far, and sadly becomes a skin scent after 2-4 hours.

So how does this compare to the original Legend? This one is certainly more pronounced, but not really any better of a performer. The smell is not the same IMO. This one takes some time to get used to if you've used Legend for a long time. Despite that, this is the better smelling one because it's more dynamic, more pronounced, and well blended. If the opening lasted longer, I'd give the smell a 9.5/10.

I am pleased to say I was able to find a new tester for about $20 on eBay. That is an absolute steal, and I'm sure there are others on there in the same ballpark. This thing could cost $75 and it would still be worth it.

Patchouli Ink | Montblanc

It’s very simple and easy to describe. A straightforward composition, yet well-executed, with an artistic and exotic appeal.

There are no significant developments; just a subtle change in the intensity of the notes over time.

At first, the ink note is intense, presenting an absolutely dark tone, slightly metallic with a leathery, plastic-like texture. This ink note blends with dried fruits (apricots, peaches, dates...), creating an aged fruity accord reminiscent of dehydrated fruits. In the background, there’s a creamy, chocolaty patchouli—a bittersweet chocolate with low sweetness borrowed from vanilla.

In my experience, the ink note is the protagonist, standing out from the beginning and lasting throughout the fragrance, though it gradually loses intensity as hours pass. The chocolaty aspect of the patchouli becomes more prominent as the ink note fades, but they always remain intertwined and in perfect harmony.

In summary:
A dark leathery ink scent covered by the creamy, chocolaty smoothness of patchouli.

The ink note has a dark/black tone but isn’t sweet, resinous, or balsamic. It’s of high quality and unlike anything I’ve encountered. The patchouli has creamy, buttery characteristics that closely resemble bitter chocolate with almost no sweetness.

I haven’t smelled Tuxedo for comparison purposes.

"I created an architectural fragrance built around a short formula. A unique signature written with iconic patchouli and a rare olfactory accord: ink."
– Fabrice Pellegrin, perfumer

Montblanc Legend Blue does little to stand out. It gets lost in the endless sea of blue fragrances flooding the market. It's not offensive or poorly made—just unoriginal and redundant. And yes, I’m channeling some frustration here, because for a fragrance released in 2024, it feels like a missed opportunity to push the genre forward.

The scent opens with an aromatic, synthetic lavender-fresh top note that quickly fades into a familiar woody-powdery base. You could use that exact description for at least twenty other blue fragrances. There’s no risk here, no edge, no personality—just a calculated, safe play designed to appeal to the widest common denominator.

If this is your first blue fragrance, then sure—enjoy it. It’s clean, versatile, and inoffensive. But if you’ve owned or even just sampled other mainstream blues, Legend Blue feels like a frustratingly unnecessary addition. Not bad, just... irrelevant.

Take the original Legend DNA, mix it with that of Burberry Men from 1995, add a sprawling base of ambroxan, and this is what you get. I'd also liken it to an updated Aqua Quorum, with that big lavender note and slightly inky smell.

This fragrance is going to get dumped on for being "generic" and I can certainly see where that criticism would come from. Truthfully, though, it's very well-executed and IMO the best the Legend line has to offer. Let's face it: you aren't getting a Montblanc fragrance for niche-like originality or photorealism. You're looking for something that smells good and doesn't break the bank, and that's where Legend Blue succeeds. It really does smell like you're fresh out of the shower, it lasts for 7-8 hours, and it's probably going to fall into a very affordable price range on the gray market in the next year or so. What's not to like about that?

I will say that if you're overly sensitive to ambroxan, you'll want to steer clear. I've never smelled it this strongly in a fragrance before. Otherwise, I can wholeheartedly endorse Legend Blue as a versatile, everyday, "shower gel" style fragrance...at least if you're not sick of the "blue" trend yet!

SUMMARY: 9/10
Fresh shower gel opening with addictive clean, woody dry down. Stellar all day performance.

RAMBLING THOUGHTS:
When I am wearing Legend Blue, and hours in to its dry down I get another whiff of its addictive clean/woody dry down, there is part of me that wants to give this my first 10/10... but I have to acknowledge that this isn't an overly original scent, nor is it particularly complex or deep. But for what it is, and at the price point it usually goes for, this is a truly amazing fragrance with possibly the most addictive dry down of the designers in my collection.

The well balanced lavender and mint in the opening do give this a soapy, sporty, shower gel profile in the opening, but it is the dry down where this fragrance really starts to shine. And this isn't a case of "just power through the bad opening" because the opening is pleasant, clean, and refreshing... it is just that the dry down is so, so much better.

An addictive Aambroxan powered dry down, mixed with smooth woods and a subtle sweet mustiness from the moss. This really is one of those addictive dry downs where you will find yourself taking every opportunity to "go in for a sniff"... except you don't really need to because the performance on this is stellar.

Projection is moderate once it settles, but you (and anyone who gets in close to you) will be smelling this all day. If you put it on your clothes you will be smelling it the next day too. It will maintain decent sillage too in the hot weather or if you are particularly active.

This fragrance does lack the fruity sweetness that is present in other entries in the Legend line and in so many blue fragrances, but in my mind that is a positive. Legend Blue is an aromatic, herbal and woody fragrance.

Its opening is sweet-fruity like the smell of pineapple combined with spicy tones of mint, while in the background it accompanies the note of lavender throughout the development of the fragrance. From its application it reminded me of Boss Bottled Unlimited and I see that I am not the only one who has noticed it, since its resemblance is notable. The aroma remains sweet and fresh all the time without many aromatic changes.

This version of Legend could be used during spring, summer and autumn, since it is a fragrance with an aroma that is versatile and at least for me it projects joy and optimism, something that I also perceive in Boss Unlimited. The aroma is youthful to mature in style, to be used in casual situations, outings with friends, to the movies, school, etc.

Its longevity for a "fresh" style fragrance has been good on me a little over 8 hrs. with a sillage that is not at all intimate compared to others in the Legend line.

I'm also surprisingly picking up in some slight warm gourmand spicy in this such as either cardamom or nutmeg. Subtle ..but it's giving it a spicy warmth. 4. Most older members don't have time for reviews---just wearing, evaluating and VOTING on fragrances.
5. Who wouldn't want to smell similar to Percival? MLB--smelling similar to Percival-- is an easy to like, easy to wear, perfect everyday scent. For 20% of the price of Percival--when MLB is presently selling @ online discounters for $62/100ml.??
6. It's said that the vast majority of fragrance buyers "make up their minds" on a fragrance based on smelling the initial seconds of the open. (This fragrance gets better and better-- AFTER THAT). See a "problem" with some of the reviewer comments here?

Montblanc Legend Blue--
REVIEW:

I'm a regular reviewer with 30 years in men's fragrance, and take pride in painstakingly writing detailed reviews to accurately report on a fragrance for YOU. Sounds weird, but that's WHY I do it. That said, it's frustrating that this fragrance has seemed to be so "manipulated" negatively, when it is indeed a SOLID men's fragrance! The following are my takes on MLB--in no specific order: For MOST men about 26 and older (ie. mature, masculine, fresh and relaxed-upscale smelling). Moderate overall performance. Best suited for spring, summer and early fall. Possessing a very attractive and vibrant open of airy ambroxan combined with refreshingly smooth lavender and mint, MLB dries down clean and fresh to a light blue aromatic fragrance reasonably reminiscent of Parfums de Marly's Percival at its core.....BUT WITH a subtle, masculine, nearly barbershop-style edge (ie. being notably smooth, semi-sweet, fresh spicy, sandalwoody, creamy-powdery, musky, with a touch of moss). Not ground-breaking, yet QUITE appealing! It draws from vibes of multiple different relatively well-known fragrances and is dead center in the wheelhouse of Montblanc's ability to master the "inspired by" modern composition. This fragrance MUST be given a "full-wearing" and worn all the way through to FULLY appreciate it. Also, word on the streets--ie. social media, etc.--is that it "positively" grows on you over time to where you will desire to wear it regularly, if not daily (ie. decant/sample worthy), while I just HUGE loved it from my first wearing at Macys. MLB has a wonderful open, transitional mid- and an amazing drydown! So you will more than appreciate it as a fresh, attractive, easy, everyday, change-of-pace, masculine, warm-weather wear. I personally expect the "Perfume (scent) Rating" of MLB to ultimately end up @ about 4.20/5 (first released in Feb. 2024 @3.68!), once the legitimate word on this fragrance completely gets out---and as the online price eventually settles at Montblanc's more typical range of about $35/100ml.....with ppl discovering this truly enjoyable composition, its easy wear versatility, and the notable value for the money. Do yourself a nice BIG favor and fully try it out!

My first impressions
Legend Blue first impressions...
So I tested this on tester card first then my wrist, first it opens a little like YSL MYSLF with a burst of sweet citruses maybe blended with fruity florals, as Legend Blue dries down one starts to get more of that Legend DNA, but it's more modern, like how Percival is to A&F Fierce, so you have Ambroxan as your base, and in this it seems to be a strong ambroxan. As the sweet citruses fade away you'll start to smell the mint, it's not a herbal/spicy mint, but more like a mint you might find in a spearmint gum, it's a little sweet, but it gives the fragrance a refreshing cleaness.
This mixed with the Percival style middle and base could give that Sedley vibe so I can see why some may say that, but for me it's far closer to Percival but not a clone of that either as it has it's own character, it is blended to be smoother which I think is the Sandlewood as that does come across, also the base comes across deeper and bluer than Percival, almost has that BDC blue vibe in the base. Performance was also great off of my wrist, far better than the other two of the same Legend line.
Verdict: I will be purchasing a full bottle of this soon, so that really says it all.

[Edit] Update
I think my first impressions nailed this fragrance, but owning a bottle has made me love it even more. Phenomenal! I got two compliments from strangers during my first two full wearings and a few more from family and friends over the past three weeks. It just works—easily my favorite Montblanc fragrance and, in my opinion, the best of the Legend line so far.

Update.
I wore it all day yesterday.
It starts out really nice, fresh, blue and only the slightest whisper of mint.
It does progress into some lavender/aromatics and very slightly reminded me of the dry down of Platinum Egoiste (the bit I like the least of PE).
However, after an hour or so it dried down to a really bland, generic, and eventually irritating musky fuzziness.

Even before the first spray I could smell this sweet and unobtrusive rose note floating through (which is so strange that it’s not in the notes). This opens with a tart-sweet freshly cut rose, beautiful and bright with a little touch of sharpness. This dies down pretty quickly in to clean fruity floral almost giving a very shampoo vibe which makes this such an easy breezy fragrance to wear. Then as it settles in after about 30mins it’s like it becomes a little more complex and ‘grown up’, almost like it starts as a 16 year old in the opening and settles in to its early 30’s by the dry down. I’m really enjoying how it sort of settles in to the skin on me in a way that makes it really comfortable as an everyday wear. Very different from the sometimes bombastic niche fragrances that can often make you feel like they are wearing you.
It’s girly, office friendly and I’m interested to see how this fares in receiving compliments.

Lovely! Both soft and strong all at once. At first sniff you really get the pink pepper and sake with maybe a hint of pink grapefruit. It’s both citrusy and light yet a little rich. It’s the scent I think a professional woman would wear if she didn’t want to offend anyone- it has that classy complexity yet is gentle in a way. I think it’s somewhere in between modern and classic. With some oak moss, civet, or vetyver it would be more classic or 80s. If it was sweeter or had more citrus it might be more modern. Good value. Lovely bottle. Lasting power is good.

I was so intrigued by the marmalade note and expected this to be a jammy goodness feat roses. Found it at nearby department store, try it on paper, can't stop sniffing it. It's rose! It's a nice rose! Happily ordered my bottle.

The package came and I sprayed it on me. I waited for the sweeter notes to show up but I got none. This manifested itself as a very tame rose then BAM! pink grapefruit.

It's unmistakably pink grapefruit. My family always kept a can of pink grapefruit candies when I was younger. This exactly smells like that, accompanied with a good dose of dewy roses. Tart, sour, no marmalade.

This does smell very safe and inoffensive. Office/campus friendly and sits very well with those who dislike loud perfumes. Not a hate but still kinda disappointed. Where's my marmalade, Montblanc? :(

Quick update: I layered it with a jammy, sticky, turkish delight-ish kind of rose solinote from an indie brand (currently not in Fragrantica's database). Now I got EXACTLY what I had in mind on Fragrantica's scent pyramid. Pretty sure there's a lot of jammy rose solinotes out there (mine's pretty cheap) that will definitely do the work.

My husband likes this. For some reason it smells very 90s to me. This fragrance opens with a youthful burst of orange and feminine florals. It is great for the summer and makes for an optimistic and refreshing start to the day. The patchouli is more prominent in the drydown, lending a stronger and rounded base. Orange and patchouli are the most detectable notes, with a biting spice from a dose of black pepper that adds further freshness. The scent is encapsulated by a very oriental rose. The texture is a combination of powdery sandalwood and bursts of zesty fruit.

Altogether, it has a very happy, extroverted and easy-going, girl about the town character.

I adore the raspberry, it's my favorite note. People eyeroll me; but...it has a "ketone" scent, and it's tart and distinct. Nothing is quite like it. Other fruits can be very similar, but raspberry is unique. I think it's underrated, and it's something I can pretty much bet on always working for my personal chemistry. That along with a ghost note of rose renders this a raspberry&rose fragrance.

In this, I wish the performance was a little better. I'm always good with a raz&rose accord though, it never hurts, and never gets old. There isn't much patchouli in here, or sandalwood. It's FREE of the common vanillic drydown, but instead stays tangy, comfortably sweet and zesty. My only gripe is that it doesn't stay long enough. It's a skin scent, so on one hand it's nice, but it won't be a contender around other people and their frags, and will be strong armed in crowds.

This is actually more of a summer fragrance, and I find it refreshing despite it not being a classic "freshie". The rose isn't too heavy, but rather it's gardeny and pretty.

Mid-June is when the raspberries begin to grow, and I'll probably save this until then in honor of them. I only have a large decant so far, but at this awesome price point, that could change.

Very sour rose, very peppery juice, whenever sprayed on paper strip or on my skin.
Dry down on my arm is just weird, a bit moldy and musty.

Not sure what happened here, any Fragranticians there experiencing something similar?

I (blind) bought my new bottle online from Notino France, a reliable and reputable merchant.
For the moment, I'll let the juice 'mature' and try again later.


EDIT
According to Montblanc official website, Lady Emblem notes vastly differ from Fragrantica's!
Fellow Fragrantician willfullmiscond already made us aware of that discrepancy hereunder - thank you ;)

Top note: Sake notes - Pink pepper - Pink grapefruit
Heart note: Jasmine - Rose Essential™ - Pomegranate
Base note: Sandalwood - Amber notes - Musk crystals

These notes seem to match my perception of the frag, that is to say, very very sour and peppery. I'll return it finally.

Most of perfume websites (BaseNotes, Perfumo.net etc.) or resellers (Notino, Amazon...) list exactly the same notes as Fragrantica's: raspberry, marmalade and so on.
This makes me question about their common info source - apart from the fact that many websites will copy and paste descriptions from others!

Interestingly, many reviewers smell those gourmand jammy notes, while they don't seem to get any of that sake, grapefruit etc. as provided by Montblanc website.

Moreover, there's no info to be found suggesting any (dramatic) reformulations ever occurred.

Still scratching my head over it.

Feel free to email me via Fragrantica platform your thoughts on it guys!

This is a soft, dewy rose scent with a touch of sour berries and a whiff of musk, sometimes a faint smell of wood comes through, but the next moment it is gone again. The sweetness of Lady Emblem is not the sticky/cloying type, and the persistent sour note in the background strikes a fair balance. It is a light, calm, and unobstrusive fragrance, suitable for everyday occasions or the office.

Unfortunately the performance of Lady Emblem does not match its price, longevity is below average with a rather moderate projection -- you may get some more lasting power when applying on cloths. Furthermore the sour accord can turn quite unpleasant in warm and humid weather, so I preferably wear it when temperatures drop outside. If you like light fruity scents or rose, this mighty be for you, else it is a pretty costly unadventurous fragrance -- nice to have, but nothing you really need.

This scent, on me, reminds me of walking through the heirloom roses at our beach house as a child. I am a lover of roses! This actually smells like roses to me, not some imitation. It isn't white or green at all to me. The Patchouli, Sandalwood and Rosewood seem to last for quite some time, as does the rose. The middle notes are, in my opinion and for my chemistry, balanced perfectly so as to not get that powdery rose scent that so many describe as 'old lady' smell. The fruit keeps it fresh and adds a little brightness- like a sweet breeze blowing through that beach house rose garden. Perfect sillage and great longevity. I love it.

In my opinion, the best time for it is warm weather, because in summer heat it can become too generic and shampoo-ey,while in cold weather - too quiet. A crowd pleaser, I don't think many people would object to it. Bottle design is beautiful and I think this fragrance would make a good gift because of how agreeable it is.
Sweet and sour, which makes it different from the majority of rose+raspberry DNA fragrances currently in the market, but not enough to make it outstanding. On me, doesn't develop over time, which is a major letdown.
On my skin, longevity is average, about 4h, sillage is moderate.

socorrosouza - I couldn't agree more with your comments on reviewing a perfume! Everyone's chemistry and nose is different and adding the caveat "on my skin" is definitely recommended, esp. for negative reviews.
For me I have often changed my mind on perfumes and never totally write anything off until I have at least tried it in all seasons and at different times of the day.
Personally I find Lady Emblem to be very different to Roses de Chloe, which it has been compared to many times here. I own and love them both but wear them for different moods and in different weather.
On my skin, Lady Emblem seems to emphasize the jammy rose, tart raspberry and creamy rosewood. The other notes are definitely there but are more of a support. The patchouli is very well behaved and settles in with the smooth creaminess. I would find this too sweet if it were not for the tart sourness of the raspberry and the balancing effect of the woods, patchouli and musk. I also have to be careful not to apply too much as it does tend to be a bit nauseating for me (esp. in hot weather), lightly does it and it is a wonderful well behaved scent to my nose.
This is also not a perfume I can simply apply without thought, my chemistry seems to change and the weather definitely plays a role so some days I can't wear it and others I can't do without it. There are a few perfumes in my collection that I have this love/hate relationship with. Weird isn't it?
On the topic of silage, I have had a colleague compliment me on my perfume in our pause area 3 or 4 hours after applying Lady Emblem! It is generally still noticeable to me for at least 8 hours and if I put my nose to my skin about 12 or more. I think I am probably very lucky with both the silage and longevity.
Thank you everyone for your reviews! Happy perfuming!

Cassandra, Lady emblem is very different from Chloe on my nose, it is a much sweeter and more citric scent brought by the marmalade , there is something bittersweet brought by the raspberry and a greener. rose. Chloe on my skin is a musky rose, delightful, but more mature, LE is more a playful rose. But if you don't like rose scented perfumes please don't buy or sample them, rather than pontificating about them (more like denigrating the scents). Nobody should be coerced into loving rose or any other sort of scents, but should not badmouth them as if being the final authority , the know it all of fragrances. If you should criticize harshly any perfume at least include the caveat on MY skin.
Also LE lasts for 8/9 hours on MY skin with moderate but enduring sillage.

First spray is pure synthetic Herbal Essence hairspray of sour raspberry accord. I do smell plenty of musk and a bit of sad sandalwood. This line is incredible, and thank god the majority of YouTube reviewers are not getting of whiff of them which keeps the online prices attainable. From the very first spritz, Vetiver Glacier opens with a robust and captivating vetiver note. It’s reminiscent of a wet, smoky, and earthy vetiver, for anyone familiar with Encre Noir. This strong opening is a delight for vetiver enthusiasts and makes it suitable for everyday office wear.

After about five minutes, some light fruity notes emerge, but don't expect any overt sweetness. Instead, there's a refreshing quality from the juniper notes that adds an interesting layer to the fragrance. As it develops, around the one-hour mark, a creamy sandalwood joins the mix, creating a masculine, classic, woody drydown.

In terms of performance, the scent projects well during the initial hour, especially with the powerful vetiver notes. Following this, the sandalwood base gets closer to the skin but continues to last up to seven hours on me.

Overall, Vetiver Glacier is an excellent choice for daily wear, suitable for any season and particularly great for office environments. If you’re a fan of the vetiver in Encre Noir, I highly recommend giving this fragrance a try.
Fragrance lasts around 8-9hrz in Indian weather

Shame that this magnificent composition does not maintain the smell of its opening, effusive, vigorous and very very cold, vetive glacier has very well put its name and Nathalie Lorson made a very good composition, although as all the perfumer are repeated many times and fall in places and common "accords" in his works.
After that opening marked by the juniper note that binds to the freshest of the vetiver with a slight touch of ginger, radically changes to a earthy vetiver with nuances 'a la Encre Noire' But it does not become so dark and although it flirts with green part it does not lead to a "Vetiver de Guerlain", And it is precisely that background of sweet and creamy sandalwood that ends giving the identity of this fragrance, that if it had a better performance would have been incredible but stays in a good composition with a fairly lazy duration especially for its price.
I think bottles were missing something to become worthy of a high range, despite being made of a very heavy glass.
Montblanc remains to us as most of the time with their fragrances although some smell very well.

Yea, this one is particularly nice. I’ve been on the hunt for a reasonably priced, modern summer sandalwood and this ticks all the boxes. I lived with the sample for a week and enjoyed it the more I wore it. I get lemon gelato and sharp vetiver in the top with a nice creamy (non-dill) sandalwood in the base. To me, the sandalwood takes center stage, and the support from the citrus and vetiver make for a very complete blend. For some reason, fresh masculine sandalwood fragrances are hard to come by. In that regard, I think this is in a league of its own. While it is different/unique, by no means is this a challenging wear. I highly recommend sampling this as sandalwood works differently on everyone’s skin depending on your chemistry. This will be in my fresh sandalwood rotation along with LV Lovers and Santal Du Pacifique.

Vetiver Glacier by Montblanc is an earthy, woody and aromatic fragrance.

From the opening you smell the note that gives its name to the fragrance, vetiver. A very realistic, earthy, herbal and dry vetiver, which in this case is not even accompanied by citrus fruits as is traditional in fragrances based on this note. After a few minutes the aroma is enriched with sandalwood, giving it a sensual, very rich sensation and then it no longer shows any changes in its olfactory development.

Vetiver Glacier is an elegant fragrance, more for daytime use than nighttime use, it could be used in any season of the year, and it is a very good option for office work.

As for its longevity, for me it was a disappointment as it lasted between 5 and 6 hours at most, and I say it's a shame because I really liked the aroma a lot. The sillage was also very close to the skin.

When I tried it I felt that it was a fragrance that I would like to buy, so I will try it again to give it another chance, but if the performance is the same again I will discard it.
Opening is vetiver. Drydown is sandalwood. Vetiver is not too harsh. Sandalwood is creamy like in TF Santal Blush

What really solidified my thoughts was when I got into my girlfriends car and she gave me a weird look and said "is that you?, that smells like that? Your wearing something new aren't you?..oh my god it stinks! You smell like the rocks from a dirty fish tank or the inside of a crab or something, that's disgusting ! "
The dramatic complaints and gag noises went on for about an hour until thankfully we got outdoors. Now, I can't unsmell the fish tank rocks and yes, that's quite accurate.
I would definitely recommend sampling first. I wore a sample of Extreme Leather last night and that much better, but I'll save that for the review of EL.
Projection is available for the profile. Longevity is pretty good, I still smell it, albeit faint, 8 hours later. Overall I'd give this low 6 out of 10.

It's just a LIKE for me. I mean there are things in it I like but the turn off is the agressive MascuWoods. I think the citrus notes got me. I like Orange scents like Boss in Motion.

I think it reminded me of a scent I wore when I went into management called POLICE UOMO...that's what comes to mind as I wear it. My wife had bought it for me as a work scent. I actually stopped wearing it because it reminded me of work.

For example this morning my wife remarked...Oh You smell like a Mister (roughly translated from french)...In which she really meant Manscent Perfumes she doesn't go for. We spoke about it in the car and she further went on to describe it as a drakkar noir, azzaro type of man perfume.

So There are good and not so good elements in this one. The not so good are the agressive woods. The really good are the top notes of blood orange and grapefruit. They totally get clobbered by the woods until they bleed ...hence Legend RED.

When I sprayed it on I got a plastic scotch tape scent from when I was a kid. The wood takes up too much space and provides a spiceness that I really would like to be lighter. This would have been a better scent with a lighter pine needle or fresh cut grass note to freshen it up.

But it is what it is. It's an ok scent I will force myself to wear. Maturing might help as the bottle empties ...who knows.

As should be expected for fragrances in the Montblanc Legend line, this is very pleasant, unisex, mass appealing, but not in any way groundbreaking. Fresh, aromatic, youthful, versatile. A good first fragrance, but there are probably dozens of things from A&F, Azzaro Chrome, Nautica, etc. that will be very close to this. Mostly aromachemicals, done well, but the cedar won't smell like a sauna or a pencil, the grapefruit doesn't smell like an actual grapefruit, and the sage/cardamom note is sweetened to resemble a candy apple.

If you are a fragrance collector, if you love unique and challenging scents, this isn't going to be your thing. But if you are just starting out, or are in high school or college and just need something that will work for most seasons or occasions, and like getting the occasional compliment, this will work for you nicely.

I never layer, but when I do I try to make sure it makes sense for some reason or another. I had stumbled upon a nice layering by dumb luck with Legend Red, I had forgotten that I sprayed it on my arm to test it out (it's been sitting on my shelf barely sprayed for 3 years) and I was going through my samples from Nordstrom and Sephora that I've amassed over the years and cane across Ebene Fume. I sprayed the Ebene Fume over the Legend Red that I applied about five minutes previously. It's amazing. It wouldn't have to be Ebene Fume, and it wouldn't have to be Legend Red, but the sharp citrus and shower gel that you could get from many options and the incense and woods you can get from many options works together.

Perhaps a bit too conform for the youngest audience, I'd say late twenties+. The notes smell pretty well balanced to me. I find it shines in humid and cold spring/summer, probably in the fall as well. For sure a pretty safe "blind buy/dumb reach", as a lot of people have already said. I won't be buying this again though, because it's an EDP and even after generous sprays in all the usual places, this apparently evaporates on my skin in about three hours. In the afternoon there's barely any, or no evidence at all I put anything on in the norning. Might just be my skin for sure, but I would recommend testing it on your own to make sure it lasts at least a bit longer than it does on mine before buying it.

First of all - do not pay retail for this one. I got a 100 ml bottle with a 10 ml mini bottle and a deo stick for €40 and it's a great deal.

Other than that, it's a surprisingly good fragrance and I don't get the hate and the dismissive comments. For example, it's way better than the uncle pleaser Legend Blue that's being hyped for some reason. It's fresh, aromatic, and memorable. It's not basic, as so many uncles here say. It has the easy-wearing vibe of a basic fragrance, but it's so much better than that. You can wear it year-round, so it's very versatile, and it's a very safe blind reach unlike many other Montblanc fragrances (Explorer, I'm looking at you).

Longevity isn't very good, though, at least on my skin, but nothing has good longevity on my skin, tbh. Still, don't expect "beast mode" out of this one. It just smells good.

Legend Red is a very likeable cologne. If you get it at a reasonably low price, it's a very safe blind buy and a great dumb reach. Many reviewers describe it as generic, but I actually think it has some personality & more than your average "red" marketed scent. The opening is very citrusy with an emphasis on the orange, but it has a potent peppery scent that makes it unique. The dry down is a warm woody accord that's fresh enough to be worn year round in whatever season or temperature. It has decent longevity of maybe 6 hours but not much projection. Feel free to spray generously. If this one lasted and projected better I'd really love it, but even with pretty average performance I still like it a lot and find myself incorporating it often when I want a traditional fresh masculine vibe.

The citruses at the top are fresh and bight; bold and sweet blood orange accentuated by the mahogany and cedar, which are both alive throughout the lifespan of the scent. The tonka gives everything a bit of a powdery base as it dries. The dry down is pure woods with just a hint of sweetness left from the top notes. Projection is moderate for about an hour, maybe two. I'd say at the price discounters offer it for, it's a decent buy. It's versatile, but leans fresh, so better in the warmer weather.
